CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

RE: Cornwall Island West School

Due to the heavy attendance at the above school, it was expected that we would be able to construct a building suitable to the needs of the community; however, the prospects of such construction in the near future does not appear to be very bright. I need hardly state that in such a small school with such large attendance, maintenance of the building presents quite a problem. We have been suffering greatly for lack of skilled help. Only recently have I been able to get assurance that I could get sufficient help to carry out this work. It is recommended, therefore, that consideration be given to painting the exterior of the above school and also re-decorating the interior. The metallic ceiling needs painting; also the woodwork in general needs painting. It is proposed to enamel the tops of the school desks.

As I have been able to locate and have set aside the materials listed on the attached requisition, I would ask that authority be given to proceed with this work immediately. There will have to be some shingle work done on the roof as well but I have some shingles on hand to take care of this item. It is expected that labour costs (Indian) will amount to approximately $300.00. If we can get started on this right away, there will not be a great deal of interruption as far as the class is concerned.

Please advise by return mail if work authorized and also forward accountable cheque in the amount of $300.00 towards the labour, it being understood that I will be permitted to purchase the materials locally as merchants concerned have been asked to hold these supplies pending your reply.

T. E. Hannah,
Indian agent.
Ottawa, August 28, 1946.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, P.O. Box 987,
Cornwall, Ontario.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

We have on hand approximately $75.00 as unexpended balance from painting the Cornwall Island west School.

There is a possibility that one of our painters will return to the Reserve next month and I am wondering if we could use the above balance to pay toward labour to paint the interior of the Junior Room in the Village School. Would you please advise.

T. L. Bonnah,

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

During past years, various officials of the Branch who have visited the Cornwall Island West School have been greatly disturbed over the lack of light in this school. The entire north and east walls of the building let in no light whatsoever nor does any light come in from the south side of the building. The result is that until the sun gets around to the west, very little light enters the building and during the afternoon the east half of the class room is still dark. One suggestion was offered some time ago by Mr. Doucet to install windows on the east wall of the building. I hesitated to give this point very serious consideration because we would eliminate our blackboard space by putting windows on this side of the building. Consequently, we would be up against the usual problem of a draughty class room from so many windows on both sides of the building. In addition, the cost of installing windows would run to considerable sum. I was hopeful, when this discussion was under way, that in a not too distant future we would have electricity on the Island and, of course, the proper solution to our problem would be to install lights in the class room.

I am happy to say that at this writing most of the homes on the west end of Cornwall Island are lighted by electricity and the power is already less than 100 yards from the west end School.

In view of the above, it would be appreciated if authorization would be granted to have a sufficient number of lights installed in the class room to take care of our lighting problem. I am quite sure that the total cost of installing the lights will not be in excess of what it would cost us to put windows on the east side of the building. Your views in this matter would be appreciated at an early date.

T. D. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 27, 1947.

Memorandum

MR. MELAN.

Re: Lighting Cornwall Island West Indian Day School.

Four plans come to mind to rectify the lighting deficiency at the Cornwall Island West Indian Day School.

1. Have two windows cut in the East wall, above the blackboard.

2. Install fluorescent lighting.

3. Install electric lights of the ordinary type.

4. A combination of No. 1 and No. 3.

Prices were obtained for the electric lights.

Two plans were suggested:

1. Install six No. K 714-48 4 lamp fluorescent fixtures. This would amount to $353.00 including inspection fees.

2. Install six 14" glassware of 200 watts each at $134.00, including all fees. This would consume 1200 watts.

The first would give 75% more light than No. 2.

As No. 2 is the usual system installed in schools, it could be considered as sufficient. I would, however, recommend a third plan.
Instal a two lamp K 714-48 fluorescent at $231.00. The consumption of electricity would be 360 watts as compared to 720 (#1) and 1200 (#2). Its lighting power would be approximately 1/3 more than No. 2 while the cost of operating would be about 1/3 of No. 2.

The original cost would be $97 more than No. 2 but this would soon be offset by the consumption, and give a light much easier on the eyes and would cause less shadows.

I would, therefore, recommend the installation of 6 K 714-48-2 lamp fluorescent fixtures. I would supplement this as soon as possible by perforating two windows above the blackboard. (The windows at the present cannot be done due to labour conditions).

This cost of the lighting should not exceed $231.00.

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Please advise, at an early date, your pleasure in this matter.

As the entire household expense falls on Miss Leaf, she would appreciate receiving a higher monthly rate than quoted above. Would you consider up to $20.00 monthly to cover this item. It is possible I can settle for less.

T. L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.
January 28, 1948.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
P.O. Box 937, Cornwall, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to increasing the allowance for living accommodation for the teacher of the Cornwall Island West School.

We infer from your letter that the owner of this house is living in the building and while the teacher may have free run of the house, at the same time it should only be necessary for us to pay for one room. The mere fact that the owner has installed certain conveniences for herself and which the teacher can take advantage of does not appear to be sufficient reason to justify an increase.

Bernard F. Neary

Memorandum:

Cornwall Island West School
Inspection Report.

School Plant.

I visited the school on the afternoon of June 23rd. It is a bright attractive building with five large windows along the eastern side. It has no basement and is, therefore, stove heated. There are two large classrooms and ample cupboard space. Six fluorescent lamps have been installed in the ceiling and provide ample lighting. There is no teacherage attached to this school and the present teachers boards about a mile away. There are very nice Indian homes in this vicinity and we should have no difficulty in hiring women teachers as good boarding facilities are available.

This school has a good many more years of life in it and when the playground has been drained it should provide a good school plant.

Teacher.

Miss Margaret Kelly; thirty-nine years of age holding a First Class Quebec Certificate. She has had fourteen years experience in Provincial schools and is now completing her second year at this school. The atmosphere of the classroom is very good and of three entrance pupils one had been recommended and one should pass with little difficulty. The attendance at this school is good and the children are making good progress. They tested well in arithmetic and in spelling. The discipline is easy and the children seem to enjoy themselves and like their teacher. There are ten children in grade one, six in grade two, three in grade three, eight in grade four, six in grade five, eight in grade six and three in grade 8.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

In connection with the attached Requisition for School Supplies for the Cornwall Island West School, you will note the teacher has requested an oil burning stove for the classroom. We have attempted to heat this school in the past with a coal burning Quebec heater unit. During my early years here, I recall that very little satisfaction was obtained with heating from this method. I think the biggest trouble was in trying to obtain the services of a satisfactory person to look after the fires. Since the war and even up to the present time, employment has been fairly good off the Reserve with the result that it is getting more difficult all the time to find someone who will take an interest in this matter and see that the classroom is heated before the pupils arrive in the morning. The teacher lives quite some distance from the school.

If your office would authorize the purchase of an oil burning unit, it would be necessary for us to install a large capacity storage tank of at least 500 gallons. In this way, the teacher could turn it low during the night and bring the heat up a lot quicker in the morning. An oil burning unit sufficient to handle a 7,000 cu. ft. capacity would be required.
I am passing this information on to you in the hope that it might be possible to purchase such a unit and storage tank to be installed before class resumes in the Fall. Should you have funds for the purchase of such a unit, it will, of course, be necessary to alter the fuel requisition and cancel any coal and wood ordered for the Cornwall Island West School. I believe it would be possible to obtain fuel oil from a dealer in Cornwall.

Please let me have your views concerning the above.

Jan. 14th, 1910.

Dear Mr. Scott,

In the discussion we had last October you mentioned that $200 each were allowed for day schools at Albany, Ft. George, Rupert's House and Moose Factory, and that the same might be allowed for Ft. Hope if arrangements could be made for a school there. I wrote the missionary in charge of Ft. Hope but have not yet received an answer. I understand however that the grants were payable for the first 4 mentioned, as day schools are carried on at those places. I have just received the half yearly statement from our bankers, the Royal Trust Co., I find no amounts credited for day schools. What is the explanation? Is it for lack of reports?

I think I handed to you or forwarded to the Dept. the report for Albany day School; and Moose day School is conducted in conjunction with the boarding school. I do not know whether the Principal has given a report of the day school at Moose or whether the reports of Ft. George & Rupert's House reached you. I would be glad to receive an explanation.

Yours sincerely,

John G. Moosonee
August 30th, 1922

Fort George
(James Bay Road)

We, the Chief & Councillors (4) at Fort George, are writing you on behalf of all the Fort George Indians to thank you for the help you have rendered us all along, but we are extremely sorry that neither doctor nor medicine came this summer, for we have suffered much from an epidemic which came from the South.

We are glad to state that not a single child has been lost to death this past winter, for pneumonia and smallpox were plentiful, but we do not know what it will be like this coming winter; for fires destroyed much country last summer.

We desire to tell you our thoughts regarding our children, for they are many. We wish that there could be a school here where some of them could be placed like what is done for children in the South; for, though they are taught while we are at the post in the summer, they cannot go to school every day, since we have to go off from time to time to hunt for food ourselves.

Fish & birds have been very scarce this summer, so that made it all the harder during the time of sickness.

There are over 100 children connected with Fort George Post who are of school age, & we hope efforts will be made that they may be taught.

We again thank you for all your help in the past & trust you will grant us the future request.

We send greetings,

S. the Chief Peter Waskitikum
also Joseph Rappas
John Matinawakum
Jimmie Tom
William Snowboy

Councillors

Dear Mr. Scott,

In connection with the enclosed letter, I may say that the Chief and Councilors of the Fort George Band of Indians approached me on my visit there in August regarding better school facilities for their children and in the course of the discussion mentioned the advisability of a boarding school such as that at Moose Fort. I pointed out to them the difficulties of maintaining a boarding school, especially in the way of fresh or country meat and that it would be necessary for them to help as much as possible if such a school were established in order that it might be a success. I asked them to give the matter further consideration and to write to Ottawa, if they finally desired to have such an institution and this memorial is the result. There is no doubt that there are a large number of children both at Fort George and elsewhere whose pupils could be drawn and that a boarding school would be a great benefit.

August 30th, 1926

Dear Sir,

I have pleasure in forwarding the March and June Quarter Returns for 1926 of the St. George Indian School.

These returns could not be made up earlier on account of a lack of return forms which I wrote out personally by the first boat in January.

I have also the pleasure to inform you that the health of the Indians at that station was very good. The attendance of pupils for the September quarter will be very large. School is continued in July and August as well as September as the Indians are all there at the time and advantage is taken of their presence. The hunters leave about the middle of August.

The Rev. George Morrow will be in charge of the school with Rev. Fred Mark, the present teacher, as Assistant after the present master. In fact he was here before the end of September.

Dear Sir,

If your Department has made any arrangement with regard to a school at Fort George I would be pleased to know it is. That post has a large number of children of school age and I would like to see them have a chance to get an education. Mission schools are to my mind a mistake, both from an educational and a financial point of view. They are expensive and as a rule the teacher employed is not qualified to teach or has too many duties assigned to him.

A public or day school at Fort George would fulfill all requirements, would cost much less to build, maintenance much less, and efficiency much greater. My experience with mission schools is very disappointing, and I cant recommend them.

I have the honour to be,

Dear Sir:-

After the destruction by fire on the 26th ultimo of our Society's Indian Residential School at Fort George, our Commission gave prompt consideration to the possibility of having an Indian Day School operated there until a new Residential School building could be provided. The building used as a "Parish hall" was understood to be immediately available for this purpose, but to make certain of this a telegram was despatched to the Rev. Principal Hamilton, part of which read as follows:

"WIRE POSSIBILITY OF OPENING DAY SCHOOL IMMEDIATELY USING PARISH HALL AS CLASSROOM (STOP) STATE NUMBER PUPILS AVAILABLE ALSO FULL LIST EQUIPMENT REQUIRED"

In reply to that telegram, the Rev. Principal Hamilton wired as follows on the 24th instant:

"SCHOOL OPENS IMMEDIATELY APPROXIMATE ATTENDANCE TWENTY FOUR REQUIRE SCRIBBLERS TWELVE DOZEN, PENCILS SIX DOZEN, ERASERS THREE DOZEN, RULERS THREE DOZEN, REGISTER, CHALK, BLACKBOARD, DRAWING SCRIBBLER TWELVE DOZEN, CRAYONS TWENTY FOUR BOOKS READERS MARY JOHN AND PETER TWO DOZEN, GARDEN OF SERIES TWO DOZEN, SPELLERS TWO DOZEN, ARITHMETIC ONTARIO BOOKS ONE TWO DOZEN, BOOK TWO ONE DOZEN, NATURE AND LANGUAGE BOOK ONE TWO DOZEN, BOOKS TWO HALF DOZEN, BOOKS THREE FOUR, THREE COMPLETE SETS GRADE SIX TEXTS INCLUDING ALL WORK BOOKS FOR ONTARIO CURRICULUM, ALL WORK BOOKS CONNECTED WITH ABOVE LIST STAFF NUMBER ONE."

The telegram was not punctuated, and the punctuation marks have been inserted by me to assist you in understanding the equipment required.
The last three words, namely "STAFF NUMBER ONE", I understand the Principal to mean that only one agent will be required to operate the Day School. Mrs. Jeffrey who was on the staff at the Residential School before it was destroyed by fire, is a fully qualified teacher, and she will be available for the teachership of the Day School.

I am not aware of any certain means of transportation by which the list of materials desired could be sent through to Fort George at once, but it will be appreciated if you will approve the opening of the Indian Day School, and provide the materials listed. They should be addressed to the Rev. Howard B. Hamilton, Fort George, P.Q., c/o Hudson's Bay Company, Moosonee, Ont. If the materials are forwarded at once there is a possibility that a plane might take them through from Moosonee to Fort George. Failing this, or any other means of transportation, they would be taken through by the first boat crossing the Bay after navigation opens.

It has just occurred to me that the Rev. Principal Hamilton's telegram does not mention any report forms, and in case he has none of these I would suggest that a liberal supply be forwarded with the other items listed.

Thanking you in advance for your kindly cooperation in this important matter,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

Some of our children have expressed the desire to be taught to play the piano and as these children are musically inclined we would very much like to teach them.

If it is at all possible to supply us with the necessary material will you please send us whatever is necessary for teaching a class of beginners.

This should be sent Care of The Hudson's Bay Co.,
Moosonee, Ont. and should arrive there not later than August 10th, in order to catch the last boat of the season.

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

W. F. Syme
June 28th, 1938.

Dr. W.L. Tyren
Indian Agent
Moose Factory, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Several of our children have asked Mrs. Greene to teach them how to play the piano, so she had thought of conducting a class if she could get the necessary teaching material.

I have enclosed a supplementary requisition for this material to be submitted to The Dept. of Indian Affairs through you, hoping that you will consider this a reasonable request.

We are sorry to hear that you will not be paying us a visit this summer, as we have a very comfortable guest room which we would like you to take advantage of sometime. However, you will be up again, and in the meantime kind regards to all.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dr. W.L. Tyrer
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.

Dear Sir;

Attached please find 'Requisitions for School Material' which I trust you will find in order.

I would like to draw your attention to the twenty-four Bibles which are requested. We have an ample supply on hand for use in the school, but we should like to present a Bible to each Graduate as they leave the school, and that is the reason why we have asked for another twenty-four.

You will also find enclosed a special requisition for a steel filing cabinet. When Dr. Westgate, the Secretary of the School Commission visited us last summer he saw that we needed such a cabinet and asked me to send a requisition to the Department for it this summer.

We have been enjoying good health here at the school, although there has been several cases of Typhoid among the people. Several people have died with it this winter and we have been taking every precaution with the children. Food has been very scarce, even more so than usual.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

MINES AND RESOURCES

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources reporting:

"That for many years past it has been customary to make an allowance to the undermentioned Residential schools for the services of night watchmen:-

(a) QUEBEC Fort George Church of England Residential School.
(b) ONTARIO Moose Fort Church of England Residential School.
(c) SASKATCHEWAN Thunderchild Roman Catholic Residential School.
(d) ALBERTA Ermineskin Roman Catholic Residential School.
Grouard Roman Catholic Residential School.
Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School.
Joussard Roman Catholic Residential School.
St. Albert Roman Catholic Residential School.
Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School.
Vermillion Roman Catholic Residential School.
Wabasca Church of England Residential School.
Waskook Roman Catholic Residential School.
Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School.
(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA Ahousaht United Church Residential School.
Cariboo Roman Catholic Residential School.
Christie Roman Catholic Residential School.
St Mary's Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.
(f) NORTHWEST TERRITORIES Aklavik Roman Catholic Residential School.
Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School.
Fort Providence Roman Catholic Residential School.

That provision is made in Vote No. 181, 1940-41, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, for an amount of $5,645.00 to pay the grants for the night watchmen at these schools;

That, as these buildings are Church-owned, payment for night watchmen's services constitutes a grant and the approval of Your Excellency is desirable.

The undermentioned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure of $5,645.00 for employment of night watchmen at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools, same to be chargeable to Vote No. 181, 1940-41, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources."

The Board concur in the above report and recommendation, and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing report work done for month ending June 30. Trust you will find it satisfactory.

Ottawa, July 27, 1925.

NADAM,

In reply to your letter of the 6th instant, I beg to say that it is regretted your letter was not received in the Schools Branch until after the return for the month of June from the Grand Lake Victoria School had been checked. Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

Dear Sir,

Having eighteen or twenty Indian families, the greater number of whom are members of the Grassley Lake Band, camped out during the summer months at North River Point on North River Reservoir. These Indians are without any school and I would very strongly urge upon you the advisability of establishing a Summer School here for three or four months yearly. The Indians will provide a building for the School.

Nothing can come out stronger than to establishing this school at once.

Yours truly,

M. James
Ottawa, June 7, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General—

With reference to Mr. James's recommendation that a summer school be established at Hunters Point, Kippewa Lake, where a number of the Grassley Band Indians congregate, I beg to say that the Accountant informs me that funds can be spared for a teacher at the same rate as the one paid at Temagami, namely, $150.00.

These Indians are presumably all Roman Catholics and belong to the Quebec side.

We have already had an application from Miss Mabel McQuire, who wished to take charge of the Temagami school, and Mr. McCool, M.P., wrote you concerning another young lady who was willing to teach there for the summer months. Possibly one of these applicants could be secured for the Kippewa school, if you decided to start it.

Madam—

The Department has decided to open a summer school at Hunters Point, Kippowa Lake, for the Grassi Band Indians, and it would be willing to accept your services as teacher, if you care to take the position, at a salary of $150.00 for the season, which should last till the Indians are leaving in the fall.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ult., with reference to the establishment of a summer school at Hunters Point, Kippawa Lake, where a number of the Grassy Band Indians congregate.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will give a summer school at this point a trial, and it has offered the position of teacher to Miss Clio Burke, of North Bay, Ont., and it would like you to see that the building is got ready for occupation at once. You will please advise the Department before you leave where the key can be found and you might notify the Indians of the arrangements made for the opening of the school.

A supply of school material will be sent to the teacher's address at Kippawa, if you will let us know the number of pupils likely to attend.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the request to continue the school at Hunter's Point during the winter months, I beg to say that I do not consider the Department is in a position to do so this winter.

The school was opened there during July, last, for the summer months, and the teacher was only engaged for that time. There is no school building at this point and all we could do was to put up a temporary shell, which would be quite useless in the winter. The Department has made no provision for this school, and, although the Indians live in the neighborhood most of the year, they have no reserve there, and I cannot find that any steps have been taken to procure one for them.

Before the department could establish a permanent school there, it would require a school site, which would have to be obtained either by purchase from the Quebec Government or from someone who has taken up land. In addition to this provision would have to be made for the erection of a permanent school building and for the salary of a teacher. As all building material has to be brought in by small boats from the railway.
railway line, $1,000 at least would have to be provided for this purpose and not less than $350 for a teacher's salary, and even this amount would not secure the services of one with proper qualifications.

There are quite enough children in the school at present to justify the Department in providing for its reopening and continuance next summer. Father Nelles, of Mattawa, who called at the Department yesterday, told me that it would have to be closed this winter but that he would like provision to be made for carrying it on permanently after that.

There are 27 children of school age within easy reach of the school. 25 of these have Indian blood, indeed all except two girls of our missionary C.C. Kellerman who spends the summer months...
The School House built & furnished by the Department are there all ready for use. The need is very great with an increasing number of children growing up without any public means of education. I understand that an order was given to Mr. Robinson at Wolf Lake permitting him to remove the furniture up to Wolf Lake. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th instant, regarding the discontinuing by this Department from December 31st, next, of its grant to the Hunter's Point Protestant Combined White and Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that, as the children who attend this school are whites and half-breeds, it is felt that this Department is not responsible for providing for their education, and, as stated in our previous letter, we are of the opinion that the Provincial Government is responsible for the providing of educational facilities. It further appears that the Indians at Hunter's Point are Roman Catholics, and that they send their children to the Indian day school which is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. The reason for the opening of this second school was that the Indians refused to send their children to the Protestant school. We regret that it will not be possible to change the decision to discontinue our grant to the Protestant school after the end of the present calendar year.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 8, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I have just received a letter from Miss Lucy Street, who was sent up to Kippewa to open a summer school at Hunter's Point. You will remember that when Dr. James was here last month he told you that a building would be available, and he was written to on the 14th ult. and asked to see that it was got ready for occupation at once.

When Miss Street reached her destination she found that there was no accommodation provided. The Indians are at the place and are anxious to have their children educated. Fourteen are ready to attend at once and more later on. The Postmaster has let her have the use of a shed for two weeks, but, as he is cramped for room, he will want it after that date. Some provision will have to be made and Miss Street says that if the Department will allow $150 for material the Postmaster and some of the Indians will build a schoolhouse at once and give their labour free of charge. We can spare the money and, as this is the only thing that can be done, I would recommend that you authorize this expenditure.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the letter of the 9th instant from the Roman Catholic Bishop of Haileybury in regard to school matters at Hunter's Point on Kippewa Lake, I beg to say that the school now in operation there is a white school at which Indians are in attendance. The return for the March quarter shows an enrolment of 25, with an average of 16, for whom the Department makes a contribution of $250.00 per annum towards the salary of the teacher. The teacher is not appointed by the Department.

There is no reason why all the Indians within a reasonable distance should not attend this school.

It would appear from the Bishop's letter and enclosures that a Roman Catholic school is being conducted in the church, as they object to their children attending the Protestant school, and they claim that the Department should assist them in obtaining a school for their children.

In 1907 the Department opened a summer school at Hunter's Point for the Grassi Band of Indians and a Roman Catholic teacher was put in charge. This school was conducted until the fall of 1909, when it was closed.

In July, 1913, the Rev. Mr. Mitchell of Mattawa asked the Department if it would allow the building and equipment to be used for an undenominational school, which was to be conducted for the benefit of the half-breeds and Indians there. The Department gave the necessary permission,
and the school was re-opened in October, 1913. The present building does not meet the requirements of the school and the Department is making a contribution of $300.00 to assist in the erection of a new building.

As far as I can make out from the census returns all the Indians in this locality are Roman Catholics.

Gentlemen,

I have already accounted for the $300.00 granted by the Department toward the erection of a new School House at Hunter's Point, North River, and having just had the opportunity of visiting and inspecting the building have thought it well to report to you. Of course you understand that the sum granted was totally inadequate to erect it. Much of the material work was furnished from locally. The Colonial Company gave the timber; the work of squaring and transporting it was done by the natives whose children are receiving the elementary education given within its walls supplemented by local friends via two teachers. It is now almost completed but fit for occupation for school purposes and as advanced that it will no doubt be finished before the cold weather sets in.

The building is 20 x 30 feet built of squared logs set upright about 12 ft. to a ridge-tie roof. It has three windows in each side with...

door in front. It is intended to build a porch the full breadth of the building. It is sealed with matched lumber over felt paper. The interior is about 14 ft. in height. The ceiling of the south end is yet unfinished, but the materials is ordered on the way. The flooring, ceiling, siding, etc., of the interior is of good materials and workmanship. The stove is not yet in place but provisions for the proper heating of the room is now the way. For the first time in the history of the school there is the prospect of the school being comfortably accommodated winter or summer. Since the project was set on foot about three years ago materials and labour have very greatly increased in cost. Had not self-denial and perseverance been exercised on the part of some of those whose children will reap the benefit thereof as well, it would have been impossible to carry this project to completion. We understand that only a small number of Indian children attend the school, the majority on the returns which the teacher forwards being half-breeds. As you are aware, this Department has no responsibility for the education of half-breed children, and we consider that we are dealing generously with this school in our grant for salary and classroom supplies. The desks which we supplied as mentioned above should still be in a serviceable condition and provide ample accommodation for any Indian children who attend. Sir:

In reference to the educational matters at Hunters Point Que., I beg to submit the following report.

There is at present a so-called combined white and Indian day school built largely by a grant from the Dept. of Indian Affairs. The school is built on the east side of a lake, on which side reside most of the white residents of this locality, the Indians living on the west side. It is obvious that when choosing a site for the school the requirements of the white people were catered to in preference to the Indians and the Indian children without exception have a crossing to make on the lake to get to the school which they are unable to do in the summer time without assistance. The white people are mostly all of the protestant religion, and the Indians are without exception of the Catholic religion, and therefore there is considerable friction between them as to which denomination the teacher should belong which is augmented I am led to believe by a good deal of interference on the part of the ministers and priests of the various denominations. The Indians refuse to send their children to the present school as long as there is a Protestant teacher and the white people want have a Catholic teacher, so as the Indians are all Catholics I beg to recommend that a separate school be provided for them or, if the present school is the property of the Department that it be moved to a more suitable site where it would be easy of access to the Indian children.

At present the Indians are sending their children to a school conducted by a Miss M. Sauve of Chapeau, who is not a qualified teacher but is apparently a very intelligent young lady. She has been teaching since the 6th of Oct. last and up till the present has received no salary whatever. The classes are held in a storehouse and there are 21 children attending, the names and ages of which I enclose herewith. They are all of Indian blood except two or three of whom are willing to pay a fee to have their children's school. The teacher is badly equipped for books for the children, but considering the way they are handicapped they are making fair progress. The teacher has no register but she informs me that these 21 children are very regular in their attendance.

At the other school which is supported by the Indian funds there are 14 pupils on the roll, who are all white children, and there is 5 or 6 of an average attendance. This school is conducted by a Miss Hansen, daughter of one of the trustees, who is not a qualified teacher. There are 14 underaged 3 of them children that are Catholic, the balance being protestants. It is to be regretted that these people cannot harmonize and run a non-sectarian school as with the number of children at this point a good school could be maintained. It is useless to try and compromise with these people as there has been considerable trouble in the past the only remedy for which is a separate school. Regarding the matter of building a new school, I took up the matter with the Indians who favor building a log building as it would be more suitable for...
that country and a good deal cheaper than a frame structure. They are willing to perform all the labor themselves with the exception of a few little jobs which will have to be done by a carpenter. All they ask is the material, an estimate of the cost of which, I beg to enclose. I may say that the rough lumber needed for this building can be obtained from the Shepard and Morse Lumber Co., who have a small sawmill 2 miles from Hunters Point. The furniture which I am led to believe is the property of the Department could be taken out of the other school.

I would also recommend that the grant to the present school be suspended at once as the Indians are deriving no benefit from it, and be given to the school at which the Indian children attend. Miss Sauve has also asked me to find out if the Department will pay her salary and also if she can get some supplies for the school.

I may add that 3 of the Indian families residing at Hunters point were formerly living in this district but they tell me they intend to make their permanent abode at Hunters Point. In making this report I have endeavored to state the facts as I found them but should I have omitted any information the Dept. may require I will be pleased to furnish it.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of letter No.35-3-1 of the 8th instant enclosing extract from the report of the Rev.J.W.Mitchell regarding educational matters at Hunters Point,Que. I also note with interest the Rev. gentlemen's comments on this matter. The reason for the variance in the report made by me and the one made by the Rev.Mr.Mitchell is that he is studying the interests of the Protestants and I made my statements in the interests of the Indians. When I made my report on this matter I endeavored to state the facts as I found them, conscientiously and without partiality, and I recommended that a separate school be provided on the strength of section 97 paragraph 2 page 54 of the Indian Act.

As I stated in my previous report it is to be regretted that these people cannot agree and run a combined school as that would be the best thing that they could do. The whole trouble is caused by the two different denominations which apparently cannot pull together, and as I stated before there is considerable opposition between the ministers and priests of the different denominations. If a report were to be got from Father or some other R.C.priest of that locality he would have an altogether different story to tell than the Rev.Mitchell.

I beg to differ from the Rev.gentleman when he says that the Hansens,Terriers,Adams,and others are of Indian blood as they are native born.The fact of a man being born in the bush doesn't necessarily make an Indian of him,they may have a sprinkling of Indian blood in them but if any at all it is very little. He also states that those mixing in this matter are whites with one exception, I also beg to differ with the Rev.gentleman on this matter.

On my recent visit to that point I saw all the Indians,that is the Indians within the meaning of the act, and they were all emphatic in their refusal to send their children to the combined school. The man Beaudreau he refers to is a Frenchman alright but he is married to an Andogwin a full blooded Indian woman and he is willing to pay fee to have his children attend a Catholic school. I say also side that in all this agency I do not know of one Protestant Indian whom I recommended a catholic school be provided I did not do so with any motives of malice against the Protestants,but in the welfare of the Indians in my charge which I am led to believe by my copy of instructions to Agents it is my chief duty to do.

I cannot rescind any portion of my previous report as I believe I reported faithfully on conditions as I found them at present. As to conditions 5 or 8 years ago as the Rev.Mr.Mitchell refers to I know nothing, but I do know that at present the Indians are deriving no benefit from the school run under the present auspices.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

The following summarizes as briefly as possible the situation at Hunter's Point, where application has been made for the establishment of another school for the children of the Roman Catholic Indian parents.

Application for this school was made by a delegation of Indians, who visited the Department in January, last, and, in order to get a knowledge of the conditions, Mr. Agent Lewis was instructed to visit Hunter's Point and furnish a report. He states that at present the combined white and Indian day school, towards which the Department gave a grant for the erection to the extent of $300.00 two years ago and to which it contributes half the teacher's salary to the extent of $250.00 per annum, is being attended by white children only. He states that the Indians reside on the opposite side of the lake and are all Catholics, there not being a Protestant Indian in the agency as far as he is aware, and that they refuse to send their children because the teacher is not a Catholic and the school is conducted under Protestant auspices. He states that there is considerable friction between the different denominations, which is fostered, he believes, by a good deal of interference on the part of the minister and priest of each denomination. He recommends that a separate school be provided for the Indian children on the opposite side of the lake from the present building, where the Indians reside, and that the grant to the present school be suspended, as the Indians are deriving no benefit from it.

These Indians have put up a shack and have engaged a teacher and are carrying on a school. There were 18 Indian children in attendance on the date of the Agent's visit. The Indians are desirous of putting up a new building, as the present shack is not suitable, and they have agreed to do all the work and supply the logs required, but require certain material, such as flooring and windows, to the extent of $250.00 to finish the building, and also request that the salary of the
the teacher be paid.

This matter was referred to Rev. J. W. Mitchell, under whose auspices the present combined school is conducted. His statement is in direct variance with that of the Agent, as he states that there are fourteen Indian children in attendance at the combined school and gives the names of their parents. Mr. Lewis states that he differs from the Reverend gentleman when he says that they are Indians. They may have a slight sprinkling of Indian blood, but, if any at all it is very little. Mr. Mitchell states that the present agitation is engineered on the part of the white people and the Agent states that he saw all the Indians and they were all emphatic in their refusal to send their children to the combined school. A copy of that part of Mr. Mitchell's letter which was in direct variance to the report of the Agent was submitted to Mr. Lewis for a further report and he states that he cannot rescind any portion of the report he made and that he knows that the Indians are deriving no benefit from the school run under the present auspices and recommends that a grant be allowed to assist the Indians to build a school and that the salary of the teacher be paid.

It is difficult to decide what is best to be done in this matter, but it appears to me that we should be guided by the report of our Agent, as the Indians are very anxious to obtain an education for their children, which is evidenced by the fact that they have already put up a building and engaged the services of a teacher.

The children attending the present school, whom Mr. Mitchell claims to be Indians, have little or no Indian blood, although locally they are called Indians. We have been contributing a grant towards the salary of the teacher of the combined school for a period of eight years, having made the grant in the first instance at the request of Mr. J. B. Klock, ex-M.P. for Pontiac, and Dr. James of Mattawa, who visited the Department with Mr. Mitchell at that time. The correspondence in the matter is hereunder.
Ottawa, March 31, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant reporting further in regard to educational matters at Hunter's Point.

In reply I beg to say that the Department, after fully considering this matter, has decided to grant its approval and assistance to the carrying on of school for the Indians residing on the west side of the lake and which will be for the children of Roman Catholic parents. This assistance will be granted on the following conditions, namely:

1. That the Indians themselves will erect a suitable building for the purpose of carrying on the work. The Department cannot undertake to contribute any amount towards the cost of its erection.

2. A salary will be provided for a teacher from the first of April, next, the beginning of the next fiscal year; the amount to be provided will depend upon the qualifications which the teacher possesses.

3. The Department will also provide a suitable stove, blackboards, desks and the school material and stationery, etc., required from time to time. It is expected that the Indians themselves will provide the fuel required.

I should be pleased if you would inform the Indians concerned accordingly and you should encourage them to begin the work of erecting a suitable building and give them any advice you can in the matter. The new building should be erected on a site convenient to the majority of the children and it should be high and dry and easily drained. It is to be understood that this building, when completed, is the property of the Indians, is for the benefit of the children of Roman Catholic parents and that a teacher of that denomination is to be employed. The appointment of teachers, together with the salary allowed, is to be approved by the Department. As the Indians have engaged the present teacher without any reference to the Department and as there are no funds provided for the payment of her salary, she will have to look to the Indians for the amount due her up to the end of the present month.

A requisition has been received for a supply of books, stationery, etc., which is being ordered, to be sent the teacher, from the Government Stationery Office.

You should explain the conditions under which the Department will assist this school fully to the Indians concerned and advise them in any way you can regarding the erection of a suitable building and have the work undertaken and completed at an early date. I shall be pleased to hear from you when you have had an opportunity to place this matter before the Indians.

William H. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming, Que.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Sir:

I beg to enclose report of Hunter's Point R.C. Indian day school for the month ending January 31st. This being my first visit to this school since its establishment I beg to advise the Department that the Indians have erected a first class schoolhouse 20ft wide by 30ft long, also two necessary outbuildings. The schoolhouse is well lighted, being provided with 8 long windows, 3 on each side and 2 in the front. The building is warm and comfortable, and is kept very clean. There is also a good supply of firewood on hand. The desks, stove and other furniture are all arranged, and there is accommodation for 36 scholars. The school teacher is well provided with material, and all the supplies sent for this school have arrived in good condition.

I had the opportunity of looking over the work done by the scholars, and was surprised at the rapid advancement made by them. The discipline is first class, and the parents of the children seem to take an interest in sending them to school and keeping them clean.

The attendance is not very large at present, owing to a few cases of small-pox having developed among the residents of this district, during the early part of the winter. Some of the parents have been afraid to send their children to school for fear they would contract the disease. The disease is now under control, being confined to one family of white people, who are suspected case among the Indians, and all precautions necessary are being taken to prevent its spreading, so it is anticipated that the school attendance will increase in the near future.

The teacher has requested me to ascertain if the Department will provide 6 window blinds for use at the school, as the windows are exposed to the sunlight, which at times is too strong for the scholars. She would also like some soap and towelling, and a desk for her use in the school, or the lumber necessary to have one constructed.

Sir:

In reference to my recent visit to Kipawa referred to in official letter No. 99-35 of the 17th inst., I regret to say that I was unable to pay a visit to the Hunter's Point school owing to the fact that while at Brennan Lake I encountered a severe snow storm lasting 3 or 4 days which made travelling almost impossible.

I could not get into Hunter's Point by team as there was no road and no one would go in there with a team. To get there I would have had to have snowshoed in there 25 miles in and 25 miles out which I could have done had I been rigged for snowshoeing, but I did not anticipate anything like that before I left here. I saw the priest however at Kipawa and he had been in there some time ago and he informed me that everything was progressing favorably at that point and that the scholars were attending regularly and that there was 18 pupils attending school this winter. Since the J. R. Booth Co. finished operations in that district there is very little travel in and out, the mail going in and out occasionally by dog team.

Sir-

I beg to inform the Department that Miss Gosselin teacher of the Hunter's Point R.C. Indian Day School does not give good satisfaction to the people of the place. Since the month of September I have received complaints from nearly every family interested in that school.

One thing that I do know is that she is not able to teach English properly. As she was boarding with an English speaking family, I thought she would soon get the right pronunciation but it does not seem so, she has changed boarding house several times, it does not say much in her favour. Reverend Father Evain who knows the people better than I do has received the same complaints and he is of the opinion that a change is necessary.

I wrote to Miss Gosselin some times ago telling her all the complaints I had received, that most of the families were talking about taking their children away from school if there was no change and that in these circumstances I thought it was better for her to send her resignation to the Department. I am sorry to say that she did not even answer me. I would be pleased to know what is to be done.

Your obedient servant

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Miss Anna Marcotte, teacher of the Hunter's Point Indian Day School, has resigned as from June 30th, last. This school is not on a reserve. It is in the Kippewa district, northern Quebec (Electoral District of Pontiac), under the jurisdiction of the Indian agent at Temiskaming. In the past, the Department has looked to the Indian Agent and the Roman Catholic Missionary of the district for the nomination of teachers. They nominate the services of Miss Christina Nephin, who has been in our employ as teacher of the Brennan Lake Indian Day School, in the same district as the Hunter's Point School, and her services have been satisfactory. The salary paid is at the rate of $80 per teaching month.

I submit, for your approval, the appointment of Miss Christina Nephin for the coming school year.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, November 19th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant relative to the request of Miss Mildred Toner, teacher of the Hunter's Point R. C. Indian Day School, for permission to close the school for the Christmas holidays two weeks earlier than the usual time.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of Miss Toner closing the school for the Christmas holidays on the afternoon of December 17th, next, and she should reopen same on the first Monday in January, next. She should make up the time lost at Christmas at Easter, next. When preparing her quarterly return, she should state thereon the dates the school was closed, and she should also show how this period was made up when preparing her return covering the Easter period. Please inform her of the authority granted.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, February 10th, 1927.

Madam:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, in which you request a cheque for your January salary as teacher of the Hunter's Point R.C. Day School.

In the letter in which you resigned as teacher of this school, you stated that you would teach until February 28th and, on receipt of that letter, an advance of $100.00 on your salary for the months of January and February was forwarded to you at Kippewa, Quebec. No doubt, this cheque will be returned to you if you left your address with the postmaster at Kippewa. As you only taught the school for the month of January, you have been overpaid the amount of $25.00, which should be refunded to the Department.

Your letter of January 20th was also received, in which you stated that you had not received your salary cheque for the quarter ended December 31st last. I advised you, under cover of a letter dated the 2nd instant, that this cheque was forwarded to you on January 8th. Please let me know if you received it and, also, forward the refund mentioned above as soon as you receive the cheque for $100.00.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,

Ottawa, October 8th, 1927.

Sir:

Rev. Father Evain, who visited the Department recently, states that the services of Miss Maria Sauve, teacher of the Hunter's Point R. C. Day School, are not satisfactory and requested that a change of teachers be made at the end of the current year, viz., December 31st, next. He recommends the appointment of Miss Marcotte, Chapeau, Que., and states that he has discussed the matter of a change of teachers at this school with you.

You will, therefore, be good enough to inform Miss Sauve that her services will not be required after the end of the present year, and you should ascertain from Miss Marcotte whether or not she would be prepared to accept the position and be ready to resume duties when the school reopens after the Christmas holidays, next. She would be allowed salary at the same rate as is paid Miss Sauve. I shall be pleased to hear later as to the action taken in carrying out Father Evain's request for a change of teachers at the Hunter's Point R. C. Indian Day School.

Miss Konan (?) cannot accept to teach at the Hunter's Point School. Would you have another teacher to propose?

The parents would like the children to be taught in both French and English, seeing that the school is in Quebec and that both languages are equally spoken in this district.

Ottawa, August 29, 1921

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the schools being built at Hunters' Point and Brennan's Lake.

Regarding your request for the Department to assist in the construction of these buildings, I beg to say that no grant can be made for this purpose. I might point out that the Department approved of a school for the Roman Catholic Indians of the Hunters' Point Reserve on the understanding that the Indians themselves would erect a suitable building for the purpose. Mr. Agent Lewis was informed on March 31st, last, that the Department would not undertake to contribute any amount towards the cost of the erection of this building.

The establishment of a school at Brennan's Lake was also approved on the understanding that the McLaughlin Lumber Company and the Indians would erect a suitable building for school purposes and provide desks, stove, etc. (reference official letter to you of August 16, 1921.)

Sir:

In further reference to letter No.35-5-1
of the 2nd of May last re, the erection of a school
building for the benefit of the Roman Catholic Indian
children of Hunters Point, I beg to report.

I visited Hunters Point on the 15th and 16th
inst. and saw the steps that were being taken towards
the erection of this building. The site chosen for this
building has been cleared and prepared, and I must add
that it is very favorable for the purpose. The timber is
all made and hewed, and at the time of my visit was being
hailed out to the site of the building. The work did
not proceed very much during the summer, as the Indians
were without ammunition for ranging or fighting fire, the
bigger part of the summer, and they also were without the
necessary funds to purchase the materials for the
construction. This obstacle has been overcome however
as the priest at the time of his mission collected
enough to defray the cost of the material needed. The
dressed and rough lumber has been purchased, the hardware
and roofing also, and should be on the ground by this time.

There is quite a gang working at the building,
and they expect to have it completed by the first week
in September. The building when completed will be 20 ft.
by 28 ft. inside, and loft, from floor to ceiling, and will
accommodate 36 scholars. It is of hewed log construction
with matched lumber floor and ceiling, 3 windows on each
side and 2 in the front, also a perch on the front. It
will be a good building as there are some very handy
men working on it. I beg to enclose a list of the
desks and other furnishings the Indians ask for to rig
up their school when completed. I have also been re-
quested to ascertain if any steps are being taken to
secure the services of a teacher for the coming term.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, Sept. 6th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo, regarding the erection of the new school building for the benefit of the Roman Catholic Indian children at Hunter's Point.

It is noted that, when you visited this point, the site was prepared and the timber required made and hauled; also that sufficient funds have been collected by the Missionary to defray the cost of the material needed, and that it is expected that the building will be completed early in September.

The Department is calling for tenders for the 15 desks required. It is presumed that the address to which they should be forwarded is Kipawa, Que., as that is the closest railway station, and arrangements could then be made to have them forwarded to the school from that point. It is noted that it is the intention to arrange these desks in the school room as follows: - two rows of seven on each side and four in the centre. The small sizes should be placed at the front and the larger at the rear.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery at the school of one box stove, to take 36" wood, also the stove pipe and elbow required. You may also purchase three serviceable chairs, one water pail and two cups, two wash hand basins, one broom and one cheap school wall clock.

Before making the above purchases, you should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers and purchase from the one quoting you the lowest price in each case. After the purchase has been made you will be good enough to forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memorandum showing the names of the firms asked to quote a price and the prices quoted by each.

Regarding the blackboards, it will be necessary to obtain the size before placing the order, and I will be pleased if you will let me have this information as soon as possible, also the address to which they should be shipped.

The lesson charts, map of Canada and school bell will be ordered from the Government Stationery Office, and a copy of the Indian Day School Regulations is enclosed herewith.

DESCRIPTION OF HINGE

Read This Carefully--It is Important.

No chain is stronger than its weakest link. Also the life of a school desk cannot be greater than the life of the hinge. In the development of the New Globe Automatic our energy was directed toward the elimination of faults in the Hinge.

OUR SUCCESS IS COMPLETE

We sincerely believe that the Hinge in the New Automatic is the strongest Automatic Seat Hinge ever invented and comes nearer to being noiseless than any other now on the market.

Absolute noiselessness can only be secured by the use of rubber or leather buffers, or springs and when such parts are used it is only a question of time till they become worn or dislodged and must then be replaced or the desk is too noisy for further use.

Those who have had experience in getting repairs for school desks know how difficult and unsatisfactory it is, and, therefore, the desk that will wear the longest without needing repairs is the most valuable one to the school.

There are fewer parts in the Hinge of the New Globe than are found in any other School Desk Hinge on the market. This alone reduces the possibility of its getting out of order.

It does not depend on bumpers or rubber, leather or other material, nor on springs of any kind for its noiseless action.

The steel balls used in the Hinge are one-half inch in diameter, being twice as large as those used by any other manufacturer, thus giving greater wear resisting qualities.

The balls in the Hinge of the New Globe are NOT held in position by means of springs, because when such is the case the spring will in time lose its tension allowing the balls to get out of their proper position, or drop out entirely.

In the Hinge of the New Globe the steel balls absorb no friction and have no wearing contact of iron against iron. In every other so-called Ball Bearing Desk there is a wearing contact of iron against iron.

The accompanying illustration, Fig. I, will give you a fairly accurate understanding of the great simplicity of the Hinge, and you will note that "A" is the Seat Arm; "B" shows a portion of the Desk Leg or Casting. When the Seat Arm is in its place, the Ball fits into Socket "Q." The Ball guided by "A" moves in Groove "S" on "R" when the seat is raised or lowered. Ball "I" rests in Socket in "R" and runs along the inside of the Casting "B" at "S" between "J" and "K." The Casting grows gradually thicker as it reaches the point "K," so that the Ball runs less easily as it reaches the end of its journey. This brings the seat to a gradual stop without jar or noise. When the seat is lowered the ball rolls towards "J" where the casting is also thicker. The seat comes to a gradual stop in the same way and for the same reason as when it is raised.

The office of the Bolt "F" and the Cap "D" is merely to hold the parts together. The bolt passes through the Seat Arm "A" in Slot "G" and through Casting "B" at "H." The notch "E" Casting "D" is placed over the Lug "C" on "B" to prevent "D"s" turning with the Seat Arm.

The Lugs "L," "M" and "N" prevent the Seat from raising or lowering beyond the proper position and also carry a part of the weight of the pupil, thus relieving the working parts of some of the strain.

I would point out that this board will not give satisfaction unless properly installed and cared for. Hyloplate is made of pulp and necessarily absorbs a good deal of moisture in wet weather and shrinks in dry weather. Consequently, care should be taken in installing this board and having it fitted in the frame in such a manner as will permit of expansion.

If at all possible, hyloplate should not be installed close to the stove, as, if so, it is subjected to very great heat which cracks the surface. Water should not be used to clean Hyloplate blackboards.

The Department trusts that you will keep these instructions in mind and have this blackboard carefully installed on its arrival. You should also point out to the teacher that water should not be used for cleaning it.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, informing the Department that Miss Honan, who was appointed teacher of the Hunter's Point (R.C.) Indian Day School, had taken up duties on the 17th of October, last; also that the desks and other supplies required to equip the school had arrived and been placed in position. The Department notes that everything is progressing satisfactorily, and it is hoped that when the present epidemic of smallpox subsides, there will be a good and regular attendance.

Regarding the payment of salary, I beg to say that the Department only pays salaries to teachers in Indian day schools at the end of each quarter, upon receipt of quarterly returns of attendance. The school which Miss Honan formerly taught was a summer school only, and opened for a few months in each year, and it is in such cases that salaries of teachers are paid monthly.

I might further point out that we are not guided by the regulations of the Ontario Department of Education in the payment of salaries.

Miss Honan should prepare her return promptly upon the expiry of the quarter, and forward it to you, and if you consider it is correct in every respect, you will certify the same and transmit it to the Department when payment of salary will be made.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

In reply to official letter No. 35-5-5 of the 19th inst., having reference to the school house at Hunter's Point, Que., I beg to report.

This school building is constructed with hewed logs, and the logs forming the walls are standing perpendicularly, and on which account it is a difficult matter to plaster the seams with mortar so that it will stay in place for any length of time. In the case of the building at Brennan Lake, which is also of hewed log construction, the logs forming the walls are laying horizontally, and the seams are plastered inside and out with mortar, which stays in its place and is a finished job, as far as warmth is concerned. I enquired of the Hunter's Point Indians why they did not build their school-house with the timber running full length and they informed me that they were unable to get the timber of the necessary length, and so had to use shorter pieces standing upright.

The only thing that I see that will make the building comfortable in the winter, is to sheet the interior with beaver board or matched lumber. There is a quantity of beaver board at Hunter's Point that has been left over from lining the church inside. This material is in sheets 4 ft. wide by 10 ft. long, and is being sold at $43.75 per thousand feet, which is cheap when the cost of transportation is taken into consideration.

There is about 1,000 ft. of this material at Hunter's Point, together with the nails and strips for laying it on, and this quantity should be sufficient to sheet the walls of the school house, which would make the building a good deal warmer.
I would estimate that the cost of this work would be around $60 to $65.00.

The beaver board referred to belongs to the Rev. I. Evans, who had it left over after renovating the interior of the church at Hunter's Point last fall, and was left in charge of Mrs. Jones to dispose of to anyone requiring it, at $1.75 per sheet of 40 sq. feet, and the strips at .02¢ per lineal foot, which is the price it cost laid down at Hunter's Point by boat.

Your obedient servant,

It may be that Father Evain would agree to turn the quantity of beaver board required over for the purpose, as we are of the opinion that it was supplied in the first instance from funds furnished by the Indians.

I shall be pleased if you will communicate with Father Evain in this matter, and ascertain if he will consent to have the beaver board on hand used for lining the interior of the school building.

Sir,

I beg to enclose report of the Hunter's Point R.C. Indian Day School at Hunter's Point in the Kipawa district. I paid a visit to this school on the 30th of September last and found everything in good shape. The scholars are making good progress, and attend fairly regularly, and the teacher has a good place to board.

The school house would be much warmer if a ceiling were put in, and it needs 5 sheets of beaver board to finish sheathing the walls inside. The cost of this work including the materials and labor would be about $55.00.

The teacher also requested me to supply her with a clock for use in the school. I purchased one for this school 3 years ago, but the teacher says that it has been broken and repaired a couple of times and does not run satisfactory. Kindly advise me if the Department will authorize any expenditure for the placing of a ceiling in this school house.

Ottawa, October 17, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, reporting on your visit to the Hunter's Point R. C. Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say it is noted that the pupils are making progress and that a regular attendance is maintained.

In order to make the school house warmer during the winter months, you may arrange to have a ceiling put in and also for the purchase and installation of the beaver board required to finish sheeting the inside walls. You should arrange for the purchase of any material and the labour required in having the work done. We note that you estimate the cost will be approximately $55.

You may also purchase and have forwarded for the use of the classroom an alarm clock of the "Big Ben" type. We find that clocks of this type are satisfactory for Indian day schools and stand considerably hard usage.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the repairs authorized and for the purchase of the clock should be forwarded for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, furnishing an estimate of the cost of finishing the walls and ceiling of the Hunter's Point Indian Day School with beaver board and chinking and banking the outside.

In reply I have to say that, provided you can arrange for the supplying of the material and the labour in having the above work carried out for the sum of $110, as mentioned by you, you may have it done. Our funds are extremely limited and the above is the full amount we can provide to complete the repairs at this school. If possible, you should obtain competitive prices for the supplying of the material, such as beaver board, lime, etc., and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. Please obtain from the merchant who furnishes the materials accounts in duplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment. You should also keep accounts in duplicate for the labour employed, certify and send them to the Department for payment.

If you can arrange to have this work done within the sum mentioned, you should have it carried out before the extreme cold weather sets in. Please see that all the work is completed in a satisfactory manner.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the request of the teacher of the Hunter's Point Indian Day School, to be supplied with 6 more desks.

In reply I have to say that, before an order can be placed, it will be necessary for you to state the type, size and number of each size of desk required. You should also state the name of the manufacturer of the desks at present in use at the school. If new desks are supplied, it is necessary that they be of the same type as those at present in use, in order to have uniformity in the seating equipment. In September, 1921, 18 double desks were supplied by the Globe Furniture Company, Waterloo, Ont. It is presumed that the extra desks now required would be double ones. The Teacher should be able to tell you the size and number of each size required and also whether they are double or single. When the Department has this information, consideration will be given to supplying the extra desks required.

Your obedient servant,

Temiskaming, Que.,
Sept. 22nd, 1924.

Mr. J.D. McLean,
Sec. Tres. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,-

I have another Mission, Kipawa, which is in need of a teacher. There are at present 10 Indian children ready for school, and a number of younger ones for future years. We have a good school built there with desks installed, a gift of some Hunters who took pity on these children. So if you would give me the authority to engage a teacher for this school, and the Gov. send the books required, it would place our Indian Missions in very good condition.

Please let me know soon as possible what can be done re these two missions, as I will be returning to visit them about 10th of October and will be in a position to arrange matters.

Yours truly,

Rev. E.A. Letang, P.P.
Ottawa, September 26, 1924.

Sir,-

The Department has received a request from Rev. E. A. Letang, P.P., Temiskaming, for permission to engage the services of a teacher for a school at his Mission at Kipawa. He states that there are at present ten Indian children of school age who could attend and that there is a good school building, with desks installed.

Please furnish a report regarding this request, stating where this school is located, also, whether the children referred to are Indians or halfbreeds. Any information you can give regarding this request for the starting of a school at the point referred to by Rev. Father Letang, together with your views as to whether you would recommend that a teacher be appointed or not, will be appreciated. Please forward any facts you can regarding the condition of the building referred to, also, if the teacher could obtain living accommodation near the school. The Rev. Father states that he is visiting this point about the 10th of October, next, and desires to be informed as to whether the Department will consent to the carrying on of a school or not.

You might consult the Reverend Father regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. H. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Temiskaming,
QUE.

October 20th, 1924

Sir,

In reply to official letter No. 35-10-1 of the 26th of September regarding the request of the Rev. E.A. Letang P.P. of Temiskaming for permission to engage the services of a teacher for a school at Kipawa station, P.Q., I beg to say that this letter arrived after I had left on a visit to the Kipawa so I cannot make as full a report on this matter as I could have done had I received the letter a few days sooner.

The Rev. E.A. Letang has spoken to me on previous occasions regarding this school, but I did not think that there were sufficient Indian children at this point to warrant the expense of the Department paying the salary of a teacher. There is a good school building equipped with desks, and I understand there has been a school conducted at this point some time ago, but it was closed probably through lack of funds.

There are about 10 children of school age at Kipawa, Indians and half-breeds, and some white children. I would recommend that the Department pay a portion of the salary of a teacher and the white people pay the balance, and conduct a combined Indian and white school. Kipawa is situated on the C.P.R., and the school house is close to the station, and a teacher would have no difficulty in securing first class living accommodation near the school. I will also communicate with the Rev. Father on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 23rd, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the request of Rev. E. A. Letang, P.P., of Temiskaming, for permission to engage the services of a teacher for a school situated near Kipawa Station and for a grant to assist in carrying on the work.

In reply I beg to say that if this school activity is started by Father Letang it is to be conducted as a combined Indian and white school. We note that there are about ten children of school age - Indians and half-breeds - and a number of white children who could attend. This Department will provide a grant at the rate of $200 per annum as its share towards the payment of the salary of a teacher, and will also provide the Indian children with the text-books, stationery, etc., which they require. It is noted that there is a good school building, equipped with desks, etc., in which to carry on the work, and that the teacher would have no difficulty in securing good living accommodation in the school. You should inform the Reverend Father of the amount that will be allowed by this Department as its share of the teacher's salary. This grant will only be paid during such time as there is a sufficient number of Indian children in attendance to warrant its continuance.

Father Letang should submit through your office the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher whom he engages to carry on the work. Quarterly returns showing the attendance of the Indian children only, should be prepared by the teacher and forwarded to the Department through your office in the same manner as is done in the case of other Indian day schools. Please inform the Department of the date the school opens, the number of children who will attend, also any information you may have regarding the building and equipment provided. This school will be known as the Kipawa Combined White and Indian Day School. It is presumed that the Reverend Father can arrange with the white people and half-breeds to pay the balance of the salary and the other expenses involved in conducting the school. Our grant of $200 per annum and school books is the total amount which we can provide.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. H. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
North Temiskaming,
Que.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that on the 3rd instant I visited the Kipawa Combined White and Indian Day School as requested in official letter no 35-10-I of January the 19th.

The School was opened the first day of this month and eight children are attending, of these two are half-breeds. I visited the Indian families and they all promised to send their children to school as soon as possible. Some of the reasons given to me for not sending them sooner are that they are not properly clothed, others are living too far and the intention to move closer to school. There are twelve Indian and half-breed children of school age, but these people are so careless that I believe Father Letang will have a very hard job to get them to send their children to school. I believe that the efforts that he is making are well deserving the help the Department is giving him. It is only after a good trial that we will know what can be done there. The building used for the school is neat and plenty large enough. The school teacher, a bright young lady is well pleased so far and is anxious to get more pupils.

Your obedient servant

J.D. McLean Esq.
