Dear Sir:

I received your communication of 23rd inst. re grant toward the salary of teacher for Kipawa School.

The contents of your letter gave me quite a shock and indicate that I am in a very difficult situation. I was appointed in charge of Kipawa mission (severed from Temiskaming) in Sept. 1946. I found the school had been operating for three years previous and was made aware of the conditions under which it was maintained. I may add here that results were eminently satisfactory - even marvelous. The other districts, Hunters Point and Brennan Lake have schools carried on under same provisions.

As I did not receive any notice of any proposed change of program, I naturally presumed the same procedure would be followed, and engaged a teacher for 1941-42 (Sept. 25th June 30) at same salary as was paid in previous years, although all other wages and salaries have been increased! As your department does not pay any salary for Sept., I personally advanced the sum of $30.00 at end of Sept. to pay teacher's expenses for that month.

Now you inform me that no salary will be paid.
by your Department—which means that I am personally responsible for her year's salary. It is an organized district. No family in Kipawa owns any property—they are squatters on Crown lands—therefore no basis on which one could collect school taxes or fees. For several years most of them were on relief. This year J.R. Booth is still operating in the Kipawa area and there will be employment.

You indicate that a report claims that there are no Indian children in that area. They are just as Indian there as at Hunter's Point and Brennan Lake, for they are the same families. I admit that they are not pure Indians but they cannot be designated as Half-Breeds—there is no such family in that district. About three generations ago several Scotch, English and French lumberjacks and trappers settled on Kipawa Lake and married Indian women. Their children married Indian women so that one could say that the great majority are 1/4 and even 1/8th Indian. I think I know where the report re Kipawa came from, and from what I can learn that party has shown a continual prejudice against that particular school—for what reason I cannot find out. Again, this year several families have come down from Brennan Lake and taken residence near Kipawa village, and their children are now attending Kipawa School.

I present these facts to let you know the conditions there, and the difficult position in which I find myself. I trust that you will appreciate the same, realizing that I had not received any previous notice of change of policy and therefore had acted in good faith. Yours very truly,

H.E. Letang
Ottawa,

When I write about the Kipawa Indians, I mean also the Indians of Hunter's Point, Wolf Lake and Brannan Lake because as Rev. Father says they are all of the same tribe.

Of the persons mentioned above I will give a few examples: Mr. Robinson, a pure white man who died only a few years ago married an Indian woman, he had a large family, two of his sons are married and living at Brannan Lake, another is married and he is living at Hunter's Point.

Also Mr. Samuel, living at Kipawa, he is still living and gets his pension from the Quebec Government. He is a pure white man, married an Indian woman and he has a large family, some of his children are married.

There is also the Mongrain family or families. The first to come was a white man, he is now dead and his widow is getting her pension from the Quebec Government. This is Roch Mongrain's grandmother. They had a large family also and many sons are married.

Extract from Inspector Thibault's report on the Temiskaming Indian Agency, dated July 8, 1942.

From the last school return of June, 1942, I found a list of 21 so called Indians, however, there are only 4 names on said list, belonging to two families acknowledged as Indians, all other names are half breeds, fathers being WHITES, and such families are not receiving any relief rations nor medical attention, therefore, why should we give them schooling.

The four Indian children referred to have attended school in the last quarter of the year but, only in part, as you may see below:

GRANDLOUIS, Barney 13 yrs. 30 days during last qr.
" Louise 12 " 28 "
HONAN, Beatrice 10 " 26 "
" Frank 9 " 35 "

Our contribution to the upkeep of the school would be justified if all the children attending school were Indians, but, when only four Indians, attending less than two months of the school year, we should, in my opinion, make new arrangements with the school authorities so that when our Indian children are attending school we would pay for such period of attendance.

While in Kipawa, I met Reverend Father McKennirey, curate of Reverend Father Letang, of Temiskaming who is interested in the school. I told him that any children from a white father and Indian mother were not considered as Indians, so that the Department had no responsibility towards such children; those having an Indian as father were recognized, even when the mother was white.

I told him I could not recommend paying a teacher full time when the four known Indian children altogether had only attended school from five to seven weeks at most.

Reverend Sir:

On my return to the office Mr. Phelan advised me of your conversation in connection with the Kippawa Combined School. It has been decided to allow an amount of $400.00 during the academic year 1942-43. At the end of June, 1943, the teacher should submit a list of the names of the recognized Indian children who will likely attend the school during the academic year 1943-44 and it will then be decided what amount can be allowed during that fiscal year. In preparing the quarterly returns the teacher should only include on them the names of the recognized Indian children attending the school. I may say that the information that we have received indicates that the attendance of the Indian children during the past year has been very unsatisfactory. I should, therefore, appreciate any efforts that either you or the teacher can make to ensure regular attendance of these Indian children next year. If their attendance continues irregular it will not be possible for us to consider renewing the grant for the academic year 1943-44.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Indian Agent Caza.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.A. McKennirey,
Temiskaming, Que.

Ottawa, January 19th, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that Rev. E. A. Letang, Temiskaming, has arranged for the opening of a school near Kippena Station to provide educational facilities for the white and Indian children at that point. The services of a teacher, Miss Florence Morin of Mattawa, Ont., have been secured, and the school will open at once. This school activity, which has been started by Father Letang, is to be conducted as a combined white and Indian school. It is stated that there are about 10 children of school age - Indians and half-breeds - and a number of white children who will attend.

The Department is providing a grant at the rate of $200 per annum as its share towards the payment of the salary of the teacher, and will also provide the Indian children with the text books, etc., which they require. Father Letang has arranged for a building to carry on the classroom work and for the supplying of the desks and furnishings. The Department will continue payment of the grant towards the teacher's salary during such time as there is a sufficient number of Indian children in attendance to warrant same.

I have to request that you will visit this school at the earliest opportunity and assist in any way that you can to encourage a good attendance of the Indian children and give any assistance you can to the teacher in her work. In this connection, I would refer you to official letter of October 23rd, 1924, addressed to the late Agent, Mr. W. H. Lewis, which, no doubt, you have in your possession. After visiting the school, please furnish a report as to the arrangements which have been made for the carrying on of the work as regards building, equipment, attendance, etc.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, May 4th, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, nominating the services of Mrs. W. Burns as teacher and Miss Clare Gravelle as assistant teacher for the Lac Simon Indian Summer School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of these ladies to take charge during the period the school is in operation this coming summer. The total salary allowed each will be at the rate of $90 per month. I shall be pleased if you will notify both Mrs. Burns and Miss Gravelle of their appointments and arrange with them to begin duties at a time considered advisable by you. You might inform the Department later of the date on which they begin duties. We have noted from the letters which you forwarded the qualifications and experience which Miss Gravelle possesses, and it is hoped that she will be successful in her work in giving the needed nursing attention to the Indians.

Regarding the drugs required, we could duplicate the list sent her, or you can have Miss Gravelle forward a list direct to the Department of what she considers would be necessary.

You will be further advised regarding the expense you incurred in proceeding to Pagwa River to perform the marriage ceremony of an Indian couple.

Regarding the teacher and matron who have been appointed to Grand Lake Victoria, I shall also be pleased if you will inform the Department later as to the date when they begin duties.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

13th March 1919

Rev. Father Evans O.M.I.,
St. Sauveur
Quebec, Que.

Dear Father Evans—

I have been at Douglas farm recently—and consider it my duty to write to you of the unfortunate Indians up there. Probably you have heard there has been considerable sickness among them. Michel Cheneau and his wife died in January, and Mathias Muller's two, was buried at Long Point on Tuesday last. Mathias I refer to is the late Sauviette's father. I am told Joe Potam's wife is very ill and her case hopeless. Young Willie Potam is also ill. I know D. Beauséjour has been out to see them, and is visiting them.

The main object I have in writing to you is this. There are twenty-one
At an around children of age to attend school
and they are anxious to have a school. This
kind of concern is not to interfere with the long
school—so through wise council teach them.
Would like to have your views on this subject
and if I can assist you in getting a school
established for these children shall do so.
Hoping you are well and will kind regards.
Yours very truly,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR J. THIBAULT,
Dated July 8, 1942.

LONG POINT.

From the annexed list, we count 29 children of school age; there is no summer school now, although I understand that a teacher was there some years ago, and used the small church as school, the Department paying then to the Missionary a rental of ten dollars per month, the teacher using the missionary house to live in. There is good work to be done amongst those families who are living together during the summer months; if we could get someone to stay there for the summer months only, not so much as a school teacher for the children as for the purpose of showing them to be clean, to cook food and bread properly, knitting useful articles and also how to sew and make over the army clothing being sent there. For that purpose, I would strongly recommend the services of Miss Bernadette Wabie, daughter of B. F. Wabie, Chief of the TIMISKAMING Band, of Notre Dame du Nord. I understand that she has not gone far enough in her studies to qualify as a regular school teacher, but she is certainly qualified to render the Indians great service in the manner above described, under any title we may retain her services for next summer months; she could live in the missionary's little house, and arrangements could be made easily with Father Martel, the missionary, for the use of the chapel. Miss Wabie has impressed me, since my first visit to the Nedelec Reserve, as a clean, bright and intelligent person, a perfect house-keeper, a hard worker with a happy disposition; being an Indian herself, and interested in the welfare of the Indians, she could render them good service.

I would recommend that next summer this suggestion be tried out, and I would be surprised if we did not get satisfactory results from the enterprise.
Ottawa, July 8, 1942.

From the annexed list, we count 29 children of school age; there is no summer school now although I understand that a teacher was there some years ago, and used the small church as school, the department paying then to the Missionary a rental of ten dollars per month, the teacher using the missionary house to live in. There is good work to be done amongst those families who are living together during the summer months; if we could get someone to stay there for the summer months only, not so much as a school teacher for the children as for the purpose of showing them to be clean, to cook food and bread properly, knitting useful articles and also how to sew and make over the army clothing being sent there. For that purpose, I would strongly recommend the services of Miss Bernadette Wabie, daughter of B.F. Wabie, Chief of the Timiskaming Band of Notre Dame du Nord. I understand that she has not gone far enough in her studies to qualify as a regular school teacher, but she is certainly qualified to render the Indians great service in the manner above described, under any title we may retain her services for next summer months; she could live in the missionary's little house, and arrangements could be made easily with Father Martel, the Missionary, for the use of the chapel. Miss Wabie has impressed me, since my first visit to the Nedelec Reserve, as a clean, bright and intelligent person, a perfect housekeeper, a hard worker with a happy disposition; being an Indian herself, and interested in the welfare of the Indians she could render them good service.

Monsieur le Directeur des affaires indiennes,

Comme vous le constaterez par la note ci-incluse, j'ai accordé à Madame Alfred Amos, institutrice de l'école Pointe-à-la-Croix, la somme de deux cents trente dollars ($230.00) laquelle somme doit être versée par votre département, prise sur le salaire de la dite institutrice, mois de juillet, août et septembre.

Les Indiens de cette tribu sont extrêmement pauvres, et moi-même ainsi que madame Amos nous voyons dans la nécessité de leur venir en aide. La situation est vraiment lamentable. Malgré leur misère, ces Indiens sont très fédèles à enseigner leurs enfants à l'école, et l'assistance est considérable.

Bien humblement,

Didier Ovain (signature)

To the Dept. General of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

I have the honour to call your attention to the official report which during the month of July last submitted to the Hon. Gédéon Guérin, Sect. of Education for the Province of Quebec, on the general condition of the Indian school at St. Isidore de la Jeune-Lorette, County of Quebec, which ought to have been forwarded to you with the two statements which accompanied it.

In that report it is stated that this school is satisfactory on the whole, which however is not the same as saying that the results obtained are satisfactory, for the general character of every school ought to be in accordance with Article
13 of the school regulations.

No doubt the present teacher, Miss Josephine Dubois, has used all the activity and energy of which she was capable and that with the zeal and devotion of which she has always given proof; but her constant efforts have been useless against a powerful obstacle and always the same thing: too large a number of pupils for one teacher, with the result so that the actual standard of this school in respect to results obtained has always been for several years been only medium.

Under such circumstances I consider it my duty to unite my efforts with those of the Rev. Mr. Giroux, priest of the parish in which the school is situated and chaplain to the Indians, in soliciting from the Government an annual grant of two hundred dollars to pay for the services of...
a second teacher who would be engaged as assistant, which course would result we are certain would result in a great deal more real progress being made by the pupils than has been the case in the past.

I hope this request will be favourably entertained.

Lewis

Jeanne-Lorette, 23 Novembre 1895

Monsieur,

Ayant appris que lors de sa dernière visite au village huron de Lorette, le 14 Novembre dernier, M. D. Scott avait suggéré et ordonné au nom du département de changer le système de division des classes à l'école du village, changement qui devait se faire le 18 Novembre dernier. Fort en respectant absolument la décision du département, nous avons prié notre agent M. A. O. Bastien de différer de quelques jours la mise à exécution de la volonté du département et de lui transmettre les quelques observations et devises que nous avons l'honneur de lui faire.

Nous croyons que la division actuelle des classes en classe séparée de "garçons" et de "filles" offre des avantages supérieurs à ceux que
que procurerait la division par catégories d'élèves "plus avancés" et "moins avancés", et ce, pour les raisons suivantes :

1° Les filles fréquemment généralement les classes jusqu'à un âge plus avancé, et doivent recevoir, sous bien des rapports, une éducation différente de celle des garçons.

2° Elles sont généralement plus dociles, plus faciles à discipliner, s'appliquent mieux à l'étude que les petits garçons, et l'expérience a prouvé que les rapports qu'elles ont avec les petits garçons dans une même classe les détourne de leurs études, quelque grande que puisse être la surveillance de l'institutrice.

3° Les garçons deviennent plus spécialement apprendre la langue en anglais, et les filles, étudier plus le français; en les réunissant, tel que suggéré, leurs études respectives ne suffiraient pas.

4° Avant la division actuelle des classes en classe séparée de "garçons" et de "filles", plusieurs de ces dernières auraient abandonné la classe, et dis que le système actuel a été établi, elles ont de suite repris l'étude et la classe et font des progrès très sensibles.

5° Que, en ces circonstances, presque tous
tous les parents des jeunes ont affirmé qu'il valait mieux s'en tenir au système actuel de division générale en classes de "garçons" et de "filles" et que si ce système était changé, ils retiendraient de la classe quelques-uns de leurs enfants, notamment leurs filles plus âgées.

6e Le lendemain de la visite de M. D. C. Scott, à l'école du village, M. P. insp. inspecteur d'écoles provinciales, faisant sa visite annuelle à l'école du village et se prononçait fortement en faveur du système actuel de division en classes séparées de "garçons" et de "filles", constatant bien comme des progrès très appréciables opérés par l'effet de cette division depuis sa visite de l'été dernier. M. l'inspecteur nous autorisait de plus à se servir de son nom et de son expérience en faveur des observations que nous avons l'honneur de vous faire.

7e On que ce système, en fonctionnant que depuis deux mois, a déjà produit des résultats très satisfaisants et que le système proposé ne paraît pas avoir d'avantages.

Nos requérants croient qu'il serait préférable de laisser subsister le système actuel de classes séparées de
de "garçons" et de "filles", afin de ne pas entraver le progrès déjà constaté en vertu d'ici et empêcher ainsi que plusieurs enfants abandonnent la classe, et les suivants agissant ainsi pour ce qu'ils croient être le plus grand avantage de l'éducation générale des enfants du village, vous priant de vouloir bien considérer leur présente requête et faire droit au vœu qu'il considère,

Il est convenu de préciser,

Hunter Reed, Esq.,
Deputy Surveyor General of N.T.,
Ottawa.

Sir:

Having learned that on the occasion of his last visit to the Huron Village of Lorette on the 16th inst., Mr. D.C. Scott suggested and directed in the name of the Dept. that the system of the division of the classes at the village school should be changed—this change to take place on the 1st Nov. next.—with all respect for the decision of the Dept., we urged your Agent, Mr. A.C. Baxter to offer for some days carrying out the desire of the Dept. and to forward to the Dept. the following remarks which we have the honour to make.

We believe that the present division of the classes into separate
Classes for boys and girls has advantages over the division into classes of "more advanced" and "less advanced"; and this for the following reasons:

1. The girls generally attend the classes until a more advanced age, and ought to receive in many respects an education different from that of the boys.

2. They (the girls) are generally more docile, more easily disciplined, applying themselves more to study than the little boys; and experience has been found that being taught with the little boys in the same class distracts them from their studies no matter how intelligent the teacher may be.

3. The boys ought more especially to learn the English language, and the girls to study French more; by uniting them, or separating their respective studies would suffer.

4. Before the present division
of classes into separate classes for boys and girls; several girls had left the school; and since the present system has been established, they returned to their studies and the school and have made very good progress.

5. That under these circumstances nearly all the parents of the pupils have requested us that it would be better to continue the present system of the general division of classes of boys and girls, and that if this system were to be changed they would withdraw several of their children from the school, especially their older daughters.

6. The day after Mr. D. C. Leatta visited the school at the village, Mr. Roy, Inspector of Provincial Schools, made his annual visit to the village school and expressed himself as strongly in favour of the present division into separate classes for boys and girls, seeing himself...
the marked progress resulting from this division since his visit of last summer. The Inspector authorized an increase to use his name and his experience in favour of the observations that we have been wont to make.

7. Inasmuch as this system, in operation for only two months, has already produced very satisfactory results and as the experiment does not appear to advantage our petitioners believe that it will be better to not to alter the present system of separate classes for boys and girls, and so not to interfere with the progress already made nor to cause many of the children to leave the school; and your petitioners, acting thus in what they believe to be the best interests of the education generally of the children of the village, pray you to be kind enough to consider their present request and do what is right and proper thereabout.
Monseigneur,

Lors de votre dernière visite à Lorette, le 14 Novembre dernier, vous avez ordonné au nom du Département de faire à l'école du Village Huron certains changements que vous connaissez et qui devaient être mis à exécution le 18 Novembre. Le jour même, le Missionnaire et les Chefs m'ont prié de différer ces changements à quelques jours, me disant qu'ils préparaient une requête au Département à l'effet de laisser les classes telles qu'actuellement organisées.

Cette requête vient de m'être remise et je vous l'expédie en conséquence.

J'ai cru devoir user de cette déférence vis-à-vis le Missionnaire et les Chefs, c'est pourquoi j'attendrai la réponse du Département avant de mettre à exécution l'ordre que vous m'aviez enjoint.

J'ai l'honneur d'être,

Monseigneur,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your report on the Lorette School for last month; and in reply I beg to say that the Department regrets to note an apparent want of discipline in the boy's class of this school, and it would like you to inform the senior teacher that it expects proper discipline to be maintained.

The reports of the Inspector and of the officer from this Department who visited the school are favorable and the Department is sorry to see that proper order is not maintained.

With reference to the Return received from this school for last quarter, I beg to call your attention to the classification of the pupils shown under the heading "class of study". The older pupils are all shown to be in Standard I and II while the younger appear to be in Standards III and IV. This is evidently not correct and not in accordance with the standards laid down in the Programme of Studies printed on the back of the Daily Register, where the lowest class is in Standard I, and the grading progresses upwards to Standard VI, if there are any pupils sufficiently advanced for that class. This classification should be strictly followed in the quarter by returns as well as in the Register, as the statement which appears in the Annual Report of the Department showing the standing in class of pupils throughout the Dominion, is compiled.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant informing me of the complaint made by Felicite Sebastien, wife of Charles Couture, in reference to her children who are attending the Indian School at Lorette.

I notice that Madame Couture claims that her children are entitled, as Indians, to attend the Indian School at Lorette without payment. I claim that they are not. Mrs. Couture is an Indian woman, it is true, but she is married to a white man, and, notwithstanding her claim, her children are not Indians and have no right to attend the Village School without paying.

Moreover, in asking her husband for payment of 50 cents a head for their children to attend the Village School I was carrying out the instructions of the Department contained in its letter of the 16th of August, 1896, No. 142,515, authorizing me to act in this way. I refer the Department to this letter, as well as to all the correspondence on number 142,515.

The Department will be good enough to remark that in the copy of the notice which I sent to Madame Couture, I asked payment for the years 1897-98 and 1898-1899. I have not collected this contribution for last year for two reasons:

1st:- because there were only a few whites in attendance at the School last year and it would not be worth while to collect only a few cents, and

2nd:- because the Secretary of the Municipality of St. Ambroise for the same reason did not send me any account for the Indian children who live on the Reserve called "40 Arpents"
and who attended one of the schools of the said Municipality.

As the Secretary has sent me some time ago the account for these children who attended the Municipal Schools, as above stated, I was authorized to notify the parents of the white children who attend the Village School to make immediate payment for these two years for their children, hoping by this means to avoid correspondence and that I would be able to transmit as soon as received the amount of the contributions, along with the account from the Secretary of the said Municipality.

I also add that I have seen Madame Couture on this subject and explained matters to her, which she understands, and was obliged to admit that according to law her children are not Indians and have no right to attend the Indian School at Lorette for nothing and that all those who are in the same position are obliged to pay. She has asked for a few weeks' delay.

I think the Department will approve of my conduct in this matter, and I should like to be informed of its decision. I will transmit the amount as soon as I receive it, which I will endeavour to obtain with all diligence.

I have, etc.,

Antoine O. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

Monsieur,

Conformément à votre lettre du 26 avril dernier me transmettant une requête adressée à votre département par le Rév. Guil. Giroux et quatre des chefs Hurons de Lorette, par laquelle ils disent qu'ils désirent que les institutrices actuelles soient remplacées par des religieuses enseignantes j'ai l'honneur, en vous retournant la requête, tel que demandé, de vous faire le rapport suivant.

M. l'Inspecteur d'écoles Roy qui demeure à St.-Ambroise de Lorette et que je voulais consulter à ce sujet, était absent en inspection officielle; j'ai dû attendre son retour ce qui a retardé ma réponse à votre lettre du 26 recue le 28 Avril dernier.

On dit dans le deuxième paragraphe de cette requête: "Depuis quelques années nous recevons des plaintes plus ou moins fondées sur la discipline et l'enseignement des institutrices, etc." Je remarque que M. le Missionnaire ait rédigé cette phrase dans des termes aussi généraux qui laissent croire que des plaintes auraient été faites, et surtout contre elle St.-Amand qui tient une classe remarquable à tous les points de vue, de l'avenir du Missionnaire lui-même, de celui du Rév. Hudon, assistant-missionnaire qui a toujours porté un grand intérêt à l'école, ainsi que de celui de M. l'Inspecteur d'écoles Roy. C'est une contradiction regrettable et on aurait dû faire une distinction, ce qui m'aurait évité le déplaisir d'attirer l'attention du Département à ce
sujet. D'ailleurs le Département peut se convaincre, en référant à sa lettre du 6 octobre dernier, à mes rapports mensuels d'école depuis le mois de novembre 1898; aux rapports de M. l'inspecteur Roy ainsi qu'à la lettre du 18 avril aussi dernier que c'est M. l'inspecteur Roy qui, seul, avons fait remarquer le manque de discipline et de progrès dans la classe des garçons tenue par Melle Dubéau, la mauvaise méthode de son enseignement et qu'elle fût remplacée par une institutrice bien qualifiée. Je ne sache pas qu'aucune plainte ait été faite par nul autre que ce soit, du moins aucune n'a jamais été portée devant moi.

La requête dit aussi : "Ces soeurs auront plus d'autorité sur les enfants". Je l'ignore et je ne suis pas assez clairvoyant ni compétent pour décider cette question. J'avoue néanmoins qu'elles devront avoir plus d'autorité que Melle Dubéau n'en a dans la classe des garçons.

J'ai remarqué aussi que les signataires de la requête ne parlent pas des dépenses considérables qu'occasionnera le changement proposé. Vu qu'il n'y a pas de couvent dans la paroisse de St.-Ambroise de Noreste, il va falloir donner à ces religieuses enseignantes un logement dans la maison d'école actuelle qui devra subir des changements dispendieux, sans compter grand nombre d'autres réparations coûteuses au rez-de-chaussée, peinture, etc.

Au cours de la conversation que j'ai eue avec M. l'inspecteur d'écoles Roy, il m'a fait remarquer que dans la Province de Québec, en vertu du Code de l'Instruction publique, article 227, l'institutrice est engagée à l'année qui finit le 30 juin, et si l'on doit, si l'on veut la remercier de ses services, lui donner deux mois d'avis avant la fin de son en-
Lorsqu'il y a une cause valable de renvoi, pour incapacité ou autrement, cet avis n'est pas requis.

Le Département comprend qu'en faisant les remarques ci-dessus, toute basées qu'elles sont sur la justice, l'observation et la stricte vérité, je me mets dans une position excessivement délicate vis-à-vis le missionnaire et les Chefs dont je ne voudrais pas encourir la disgrâce. Aussi, j'espère qu'en les informant du résultat de cette question, le Département voudra bien les mettre sous l'impression qu'il a agi de son propre chef, sans que mes remarques y aient contribué pour quoi que ce soit.

J'ai l'honneur d'être,

Monsieur,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Sauvages.

Sir:

In accordance with your letter of the 26th April last, forwarding me a petition addressed to your Department by the Rev. Guil. Giroux and four of the Huron Chiefs of Lorette, in which they state that they desire that the present school Teachers be replaced by religious teachers, I have the honour, in returning you the petition as requested, to report as follows:

Mr. Roy, Inspector of Schools, who resides at St. Amébroise de Lorette and whom I wished to consult in the matter, was absent on official inspection and I had to wait until his return, which delayed my reply to your letter of the 26th, received on the 28th of April last.

In the second paragraph of this petition it is stated "For some years we have received complaints more or less well founded as to the discipline and the teaching of the Teachers, etc." I regret that the Missionary couched this phrase in terms so general as to lead one to believe that complaints had been made, and especially against Miss St. Amand, who conducts a class remarkable in all respects according to the acknowledgment of the Missionary himself and of the Rev. Mr. Hudon, Assistant Missionary, who has always taken great interest in the School, as well as of Mr. Roy, the School Inspector. This contradiction is to be regretted and a distinction ought to have been made which would have saved me the unpleasantness of drawing the attention of the Department to this matter.

Besides,
Besides, the Department can satisfy itself by referring to its letter of the 6th October last, to my monthly school reports since the month of November, 1898, to the reports of Inspector Roy, and to my letter of the 18th of April last, that it was Mr. Roy and [illegible] alone remarked the want of discipline and of progress in the boys' class conducted by Miss Dubeau, the bad method of teaching and that she ought to be replaced by a well qualified teacher. I do not know of any complaint having been made by any person else whomsoever—at least none has been made to me.

The petition states also "These sisters would have more authority over the children". I am not aware of it and I have not sufficient insight nor am I competent to decide that question. I acknowledge, nevertheless, that they would have more authority than Miss Dubeau has over her class of boys.

I observe also that the signers of the petition do not speak of the considerable expense that the proposed change would necessitate. As there is no convent in the Parish of St. Ambroise de Lorette, it would be necessary to give these religious teachers lodging in the present school-house, which would have to be changed at some expense without considering the great number of costly repairs to the ground floor, painting, etc.

In the course of a conversation that I had with Inspector Roy the latter remarked to me that in the Province of Quebec under the Code of public instruction, Section 227, the school teacher is engaged for the year that ends on the 30th of June, and that, if it is desired to dispense with her services, she ought to be given two months' notice before the end of her engagement. When there is a valid cause for dismissal for incapacity or otherwise, this notice is not required.

The Department will understand that in making the foregoing
foregoing remarks, all based as they are on justice, observation and strict truth, I place myself in an exceedingly delicate position in respect to the Missionary and the Chiefs, whose disfavour I should not like to incur. Also I trust that in informing them of the decision in regard to this question the Department will be kind enough to give them the impression that it has acted of its own motion, without being influenced by any remarks from me.

I have, etc.,

Antoine O. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

OTTAWA, 16th May, 1899

The Secretary:

Re petition of Missionary and Huron Chiefs of Lorette to have the present teachers of their school replaced by the Sisters.

Mr School Inspector Roy in his report on the Jeune Lorette school for the year ended 30th June, '98, stated that he found the discipline in the boys' class very bad and that he had been obliged on several occasions to speak to the teacher about her want of control over the pupils and the unsatisfactory results obtained. Mr Agent Bastien was written to in the matter of the complaint made against Miss Dubéau, the teacher of the boys' class and he reported that she, being very old, had lost her authority over the pupils and that it was impossible for her to maintain discipline in her class. The teacher was written to on this subject and informed that unless a marked improvement took place the question of continuing her in her present position would receive serious consideration.

Miss Dubéau, having had charge of this school for a number of years and conducting it with fair success, the Department did not wish to act harshly towards her and was willing to give her every opportunity of obtaining better control over her pupils, in which I regret to say, judging by the reports received, she has not succeeded. I might mention here that in '95, Miss Dubéau voluntarily consented to the division of her salary to pay for the services...
of an assistant, and Miss Elizabeth St Amand was appointed in September of that year, both teachers receiving a salary of $150 per annum, $300 being the sum voted for the school.

Mr Bastien, the Agent, and the Inspector, report favorably of the manner in which Miss St Amand conducts her class, and there does not appear to be any reason for her dismissal. Miss Dubéau should, I think, be retired from the 30th June next, and I understand from Mr Bastien's report that she will be entitled to a retiring allowance from the Quebec Government, as she has been teaching for over 25 years. He also states that she is comfortably off, being worth $4000 or $5000.

In the petition referred to the Indians ask to have the Sisters placed in charge of this school, and Mr Bastien, to whom the petition was referred for report, states that he observes that the signers of the petition do not speak of the considerable expense which the proposed change would necessitate. As there is no convent in the parish of St Ambrose de Lorette, it would be necessary to give the religious teachers lodging in the present school house, which would have to be changed, at some expense, without considering the great number of costly repairs to the ground floor, painting, etc.

If the Department feels disposed to go to any additional expense in connection with this school, it seems to me that it would be better that the money should be expended in securing the services of a properly qualified head teacher for this school, as
$150 is not sufficient compensation for a competent teacher. The Hurons of Lorette pay about $75 or $80 a year for school material, fuel and inspection of their school and their capital would not stand a much larger expenditure as they have only about $4500 to their credit.

The return for last quarter shows an enrollment of 75 pupils and two teachers are required for a school of this size, who should hold recognized Provincial certificates of qualification.

Memorandum:

Miss Josephine Dubéau, who has been head teacher of the Jeune Lorette school for a number of years, writes under date of the 16th instant, that it is currently reported in the village that the Sisters are going to take charge of the school in the fall, and that her services will not be required after the holidays. Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 27th inst., there are three water-closets that we have without ventilation; there is one in each vestry for the pupils, the other is in the dormitory of the nuns. There are no ventilators in the school-rooms and there is hardly an hour when the pupils are in class that we have not to open the window in order to get a little fresh air. The air is so vitiated that it is suffocating.

Will you have the great kindness to authorize our physician, Dr.J.E.Vermet, of Lorette, to make a inspection of the convent; he is very competent and will be able to give you a very thorough report. For a year he has been finding fault with this building, very much, from a sanitary standpoint. If you will write to him, it will save you sending an inspector. This building was erected in accordance with plans from Ottawa, and the Government sent an inspector last winter. We did not say anything, because that gentleman ought to be in a position to know well what is needed for these class-rooms. It is for the Government to attend to this matter.

I send you a plan, very simple, of the building.

Yours very humbly,

Sister St.Jean de la Croix,
Superior.
Madame la Supérieure,
Couvent de l'Indian Lorette,
Jeanne Lorette, Co., Québec.

J'ai l'honneur d'être, Madame,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

The Superior,

Madam,

We have been informed by letter (1) that your convent contains three water-closets that have no ventilation, (2) that "the nuns are obliged to open the windows of the class-rooms, and that at this season this is too cold."

We are writing to our correspondent asking him to give us further details as to the way in which these conveniences are constructed, and we will write to you later on.

With reference to the class-rooms, it appears to us that your school has not the proper amount of ventilation and consequently the Board directs me to call your attention to the three sections, 69K, 69L and 69M of the regulations in regard to schools, a copy of which is inclosed herewith, and to beg you to provide the ventilation therein prescribed.

I also inclose a copy of a printed form in regard to ventilation of schools.

You will find therein at pages 14 and 15 some facts that indicate how stoves ought to be used to provide a system of ventilation.

I have, &c.,
Elzear Pelletier, M.D.,
Secretary.

Mr. Frank Padley,
Deputy Minister of I.A.,

Sir,

In all confidence I beg to ask you two favours: the first is as follow: you compel us to teach until noon and until four o'clock. I beg to tell you that in these circumstances it is absolutely impossible for us to prepare our food, to take our meals, and to oversee the recreation of the pupils; and as for themselves, these poor children, have they time enough for their digestion without interfering with their class? I may say that at noon, especially, we are very much pressed. If you insist absolutely on our following this regulation, could you not add a few dollars to pay for a sister who would do the cooking for us, so that although the work would still be felt, at least it would be a little lightened. I leave it to your discretion as to the amount to give; all the same, $50.00 would not be too much to keep another sister for the kitchen, would it? In the second place, the Government wishes to promote education; I do not think that it would be too much to ask whether you would be so kind as to provide our little house with electric light; our little Hurons would benefit by it during the dark days of autumn and winter.

Confident in your liberality, I should ask God
to bestow upon you in return the choice favours that it pleases Him to grant to those who direct others when they do so with disinterestedness such as we know to be the case with you.

I append to my letter a list of the books, exercise-books and other school material for our classes. I trust that, as in the past, you will continue to send direct the articles asked for. Could you not with that purpose permit me to purchase myself at Quebec, what is mentioned in the requisition; we should receive them sooner because our pupils are in want of necessary things.

Accept the profound respect with which I have the honour to be, Sir,

Yours very humbly and gratefully,
Mother St. Jeanne de Chantal

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

In connection with my memorandums of the 13th and 16th instant regarding increases in the salaries to the teachers of the Restigouche Indian Day School and showing the salaries received by the teachers at Lorette and Pointe Bleue I beg to again draw your attention to the amount allowed for salaries to the teachers at the last named schools and would also draw attention to the salaries paid to the teachers at the Bérénice School.

At Lorette the principal and assistant each receive $250.00 per annum and the bonus, or a combined salary and bonus of $400.00.

At Pointe Bleue the principal is paid $300.00 per annum and the assistant $250.00. They also each receive the bonus of $150.00, thus making the amount received by the Principal $450.00 and the assistant $400.00.

At Bérénice the teachers are paid $275.00 each and they also receive the bonus of $150.00, a combined salary and bonus of $425.00.

The salaries of the two teachers at Restigouche have recently been increased and they receive, from the first of October, last, salaries as follows: principal $450.00 and the assistant $350.00.

I would recommend that the salaries of the teachers at the Lorette, Pointe Bleue and Bérénice Schools be increased to the same amount as at Restigouche, as the teachers at all these schools have a large attendance and perform the same duties and they are giving satisfaction in their work. At Restigouche there was an enrolment of 87 pupils with an average...
of about 50; at Lorette the enrolment is 65 pupils and the average attendance 60; at Pointe Bleue the enrolment is 82 with an average attendance of 62 and at Bersimis the enrolment during six months of year is about 96 and for the September quarter last, the average attendance was 92. During the winter the Indians are away hunting and the enrolment at the Bersimis School is about 25, with an average of 21.

If my recommendation is approved, the salary of the principal of Lorette should be increased by $200.00 and the assistant by $100.00; at Pointe Bleue the salary of the principal should be increased by $150.00 and the assistant by $100.00 and at Bersimis the salary of the principal should be increased by $175.00 and the assistant by $75.00. By allowing these increases the salaries at these three schools will be the same as paid the teachers at Restigouche. There is practically the same amount of work to be done at all these schools and the teachers have the same qualifications. If these increases are approved by you they should date from the first of October, last, the beginning of the present quarter.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Jules Sioui of the Lorette Reserve protesting against the dates between which the Lorette School will be operated during the academic year 1941-42.

As you were notified in official letter of the 29th ultimo the matter of opening and closing dates was very carefully considered this year and it was felt that the opening and closing dates of all Indian day schools should be uniform. For this reason you were advised that the Lorette School would open on October 1, 1941, and close on June 30, 1942. You should so advise Sioui.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Re: Lorette Indian Reserve

On September 17 I visited this reserve and accompanied by Indian Agent Bastien we inspected the Lorette Indian Day School. This is a very old building two stories high. The two class rooms are on the ground floor and the teachers' living quarters on the second floor. The enrolment at this school is 62 and the class rooms are rather small to accommodate this number of children. However, the whole building was extremely clean and in fairly good repair but the roof will require extensive repairs in the very near future and due to the construction of a new highway in front of the school property the water from the highway drains into the cellar. It will be necessary to construct some kind of a drain to carry the water from the cellar. Indian Agent Bastien is making inquiries regarding the cost of the necessary work and will later advise the Department. If the expenditure recommended by Mr. Bastien is at all reasonable I believe that this work should be done this fall.

While the Sisters in charge of this school have only conducted classes to Grade 6 in the past it is their intention to conduct Grade 7 this year.

For many years it has been the custom to send the best of the oldest boys to the Brothers' School. At this school they take a three-year course which includes considerable commercial work. Indian Agent Bastien was very insistent on the fact that the older boys should be handled by men and in addition he stated that the training they receive at the Brothers' School enables them to secure positions.
When the staff of the Lorette School only taught up to the sixth grade those who attended the Brothers' School had to stay for three years. However, with Grade 7 instruction in our own school it will only involve sending the brighter boys to the Brothers' School for a period of two years.

For the current academic year we have authorized grant of $30.00 each for 11 boys to attend the Brothers' School. Both the Indian Agent and the Sisters agreed that this was the total number who were entitled to the additional training this year. I pointed out to them that it was unlikely that this number could be increased in future years and I believe they thoroughly understand that in future the Department will only allow a maximum of 11 at the Brothers' School. The tuition fee is $30.00 a year each.

In addition to the regular academic subjects some vocational training has been given along practical lines and, as a matter of fact, the fence around the school property was constructed by the boys under the direction of the Sister.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This is just a line to tell you about the children of Mr. Ernest Savard. My little boy, aged 7, has just begun to go to school, his first year, since which time he has been mistreated. He has arrived at school with a tooth broken, the result of a blow from Ernest Savard's little boy, who is much older and bigger. The family of Ernest Savard, who are on the Reserve, are pure Canadians. Several have complained about this family, who pass their time in playing tricks and doing harm everywhere in the village. I told the parents but they pay no attention to their children; they cannot correct them and are obliged to let them do what they like. If this keeps on I shall have to take my children out of school. Please see to the matter as soon as possible. What have things come to that Canadians living on the Reserve have more say than we Indians. The people of the Village all have complaints to make about mistreatment by the Savard family.

(sgd.) Mrs. Alexandre Sioui,

Following his last inspection of your school at the beginning of February, Mr. Doucet reported that you have made a radical change in your Course of Studies. You are introducing the teaching of English where such instruction is not required by provincial regulations.

The Department does not wish to jeopardize the success of the pupils in their studies for this year. We are, therefore, not ready to authorize such radical changes that may cause the failure of these pupils. Should there be any changes necessary you will be officially notified so that they may be made at the beginning of the academic year 1947-48.

Mr. R. A. Hoey, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

We acknowledge with thanks your letter of March 4th re: Extracurricular English being taught in our school. Our delay in answering is due to the fact that we communicated with the general authority at our Mother-House.

We confess to being positively taken aback by your statement that you "are not ready to authorize such radical changes...", in view of the fact that these changes were very high-handedly imposed upon us by your own local Indian Agent, Mr. Maurice Bastien, who gave us the impression that he was acting officially, on behalf of the Department. Our Reverend Mother, early in December, sent a personal representative here to beg Mr. Bastien that these changes be not enforced in the very middle of the school-year, for this placed her in the greatest embarrassment, but he was adamant and threatened to place a masculine lay-teacher in the school unless his requirements be immediately fulfilled.

Furthermore, when, on Jan. 22nd, we remarked to Mr. Bastien that we had received no direct communication from Ottawa asking us to undertake the teaching of English on a larger scale, he replied that that was because he had smoothed out things for us and that the Department (following upon the visit of the Indian Commission last fall) positively required more English to be taught in our school.

Acting in very good faith, and convinced that she was cooperating with the Department, Reverend Mother went to no end of trouble to find a bilingual teacher, and that teacher has been here since Jan. 8th, teaching one and one-half hours a day, absolutely without remuneration!
We would like to call your attention to the fact that, to give weight to his arguments, Mr. Bastien very often invokes the existence of a "contract" which is supposed to oblige us to furnish bilingual teachers and bilingual teaching such as is done in the separate schools of Ontario. Neither Reverend Mother nor myself have any knowledge of such a contract nor can find any trace of it in the Community archives. Now, if such a contract exists, we suppose it to have been passed by former superiors with the Department at Ottawa, and you would greatly oblige us by sending us an exact copy. If, on the other hand, such contract was passed with Mr. Bastien, did he have the right to include clauses which are in contravention with the School Laws of the Province? At any rate, should such be the case, will you please oblige us by asking Mr. Bastien to send you an exact copy of this document, and forward same to us? We shall be very grateful if you can elucidate this "contract" question once and for all.

In accordance with your letter, we have of course resumed the teaching of English exactly in accordance with Provincial requirements, i.e., two hours a week, in grades six and seven, only.

We greatly regret that we can produce no written document to substantiate the above affirmations. All arrangements were made verbally with the Indian Agent. On our part, as we are always very straightforward in our dealings, we had absolutely no idea that we were being taken in.

Please excuse the almost unreasonable length of this missive. In all justice to our Community we feel that these explanations are necessary.

Awaiting your further good pleasure and eager to receive a copy of the "contract" which we know you will have the courtesy to send us, I remain,

Yours very sincerely,
S. Ste. Jeanne d'Arc, Principe,
Sister Ste. Jeanne d'Arc, Principal.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Inspection of Lorette Indian Day School.

Accompanied by Superintendent Bastien, I visited the two classrooms of the Lorette Indian Day School. There are sixty pupils enrolled and I am told that there are quite a few that should attend but do not because of lack of accommodation. In order to make a clear picture, I have asked the Superior to send me a list of all the pupils of school age that are not enrolled at the school but are enrolled in some Provincial school or other institution of learning and also those who are not attending any school whatever. I am inclined to believe that this situation can be remedied without increasing our educational facilities at this place. It must be remembered that Lorette is far advanced in the field of assimilation and I believe it would be a mistake to try to retard this improvement by isolating them in the field of education.

I promised to return to this Reserve some time in the Spring in order to study this situation a little better and also to consider the problem of repairs to the roof of the school. This is an old building probably fifty years old and due to war conditions certain repairs were neglected. The leakage takes place in the valleys along the dormer windows. The main roof has been thoroughly repaired. It would even be necessary to repair the slanting portion as this building is a French roof style.
I have asked the agent to clear the snow from these portions as soon after the snow falls as possible so as to prevent its seepage into the interior.

The teachers have drawn my attention to the difficulty of teaching several grades, especially the higher grades. In the senior room at Lorette grades, 4, 5, 6 and 7 are taught. I cannot agree that this is exceptionally heavy work. However, we know this is a problem that has to be solved in many of our schools and is one which has been met adequately in a number of them by the adaptation of methods different from the traditional methods used at some schools. The number enrolled in this school in each grade would not justify us making a new class in order to re-divide these pupils. There are only thirty-three in the senior room.

It is regrettable that these schools can not be visited more frequently in order to guide these teachers in the division and teaching of the various classes. However, this is a question of personnel and may some day be remedied.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have received your letter and understand your concern regarding the condition of the school at the Village of Lorette. I am informed that the Department could not accommodate any additional students due to the school being overcrowded and unable to accommodate more pupils.

I do not wish by these remarks to make personally as a Huron Indian, to force the hand of the Department in the matter, and had it not been for the emphatic refusal not called for by my request,
I should have willingly kept silent. The request was so simple and so natural that I did not think it necessary to mention in my letter of the 16th Dec last that I had previously obtained from the chiefs of the tribe written permission to occupy without charge this half of the basement of the school the occupation of which would not harm anyone.

This refusal makes me more inclined to argue as to my quality as a Huron Indian than a full right to occupy a piece of land which belongs to me as much as to any one else in the tribe. There is no doubt as far as land on the reserve is concerned that it is recognized that white men have a monopoly of the privilege. When in 1870 Mr. Henry O'Sullivan, a white man, wished to obtain permission to use water power on the St. Charles River, which borders on the reserve, for the supply of his own house,
in spite of the fact that the Department had fixed an annual rent of $15 or security for double that amount, the Department went back on its decision and graciously and gratuitously placed this water power at his disposal (see correspondence unfinished of 1879 and 1870, No. 3322).

I am not aware what were the conditions on which a lease was issued in 1890 to Mr. Reid, another white man, to occupy the St. Charles River near his paper mill; it was a question at the time, and the chiefs decided to make him pay $50 a year. The correspondence under the same number has also remained unfinished. But I know that then Mr. Reid put an agreement through the reserve for his personal use and the Department at once accepted the condition of $50 a year suggested by the chief (see the same number of correspondence)

Dr. Hamel for several years
occupied not only the part of the cellar for the use of the school, but the whole of the cellar and half of the ground floor where the class-room now is and all the garret, without the Department making any objection, as I am aware.

Mr. Howell was also a white man.

The proprietors of the Quebec & St. John Railway Company are also white men, since they without difficulty they obtained a remission of the damage done on the Guarantee Reserve by the passage of their railway, without ever obtaining either permission or authority from the Department.

It is probably also my quality of being an Indian which interferes in my receiving a reasonable salary an increase in which I asked for at the request of the missionary and the chiefs with the influence and recommendation of the most influential minister of the Quebec...
Government.

This being us of the Huron property and of the right reserved by the Hurons I feel more than all the refusal which I can suffer.

And if in my quality of being a Huron Indian I make these remarks, it is not with the object of making the Department go back on its decision that it has been expressed to me in its letter of the 20th Dec. I can disagree with this position, which is not one, since with the permission of the chief I have a right to occupy this basement except the satisfaction of the Department and provided that no inconvenience would result to the school. But I must remark that although only an uncivilized Indian, I understand perfectly what a refusal is and how far ones are given.

Sincerely,

Antoine O. Bastien,
Huron Indian

Jeanne Lorette, 17 Oct. 1876.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the project of drains that have constantly to be made on the floor of the schoolhouse in the village of Lorette.

The ground-floor of the school is lower than the level of the public road and when the water rises, especially in spring and fall, it covers this floor for a height of about two feet—a fact that I have seen myself—and causes damage to the house. It is therefore necessary that a drain should be made to conduct the water down the other side of the road.

I visited the spot and obtained an estimate of the work to be done from a mechanic familiar with such work; he told me that the necessary work will cost at least $950. Further amount...
the closets, which are in a very bad condition, can be repaired, the broken windows on the ground floor put right, and the floor made proper for the house. For this purpose it would be necessary to dig a drain about 3 feet deep and 50 feet long under the public road, which is unadorned, and to build some at the openings of the drain, which should be enclosed in a box of brick plank.

The tender made seems to me to be very low considering the work to be done, which is urgent, the fall being already well on.

Will the Department kindly authorize me in the matter as soon as possible.

Yours, etc.,
R. O. Baxter
Indian Agent.

Specification for repairs to the schoolhouse in the Huron Village of Lorette.

To pull down the old roof and make a fresh roof and to cover it with cedar shingles and to make eight sky-lights and three windows in the gables with windows inside and outside, all the inside to be finished in one inch beaded pine boards, to make a partition in the middle with two thicknesses of boards and upright joists in the middle with a door in this partition. The other divisions shall be made with one inch boards separated into three or four at the request of the occupant, the necessary doors to be made and three or four wardrobes, all the walls up to the plastering to be filled with sawdust and three inches of sawdust to be placed on the ceiling and to lay boards over the small garret if need be, and a set of steps to mount to the small garret and an inclosed staircase from the first floor to the second.

Also was (not visible) on each flat, with a door through the wall.

The floor to be double, of pine one and a half inches over 27x47, and the chimney to be lengthened if need be in good brick.

The room used as a private apartment shall be divided to suit the taste of the occupant.

With a gallery 5x47 feet covered with boards and shingles supported by pillars and the lower part carved, the underneath of the roof to be ceiled, a stair at each end, and two coats of paint over the whole of the new lumber and one coat only on the old walls outside. A coat of black oil on the roof.

The windows and doors to be painted and the necessary things as well as the wardrobes.

All the work shall be well done and the
walls shall be repaired.

This work is estimated at $525.

G. Giroux,
Missionary Priest.

If the roof remains as it is, the price will be $425.

It would be much better to build another roof and so make a good class-room under this roof, and a better apartment for the teachers. This is the desire of the Chief.

G. Giroux,
Missionary Priest.

OTTAWA, 4th July, 1900.

The Secretary:

In reference to Rev. Father Giroux's letter to Hon. Mr Fitzpatrick on the subject of repairs which he states should be made to the schoolhouse in the Huron Village of Lorette, I beg to say that plans and specifications showing the required repairs were received from Father Giroux yesterday. His estimate of the cost of the work is $250.00.

I know of no funds that would be available for this purpose, as there is no provision in the estimates for any repairs to this school, and the capital of the Band, which amounts to only about $4000, would hardly stand this outlay, as the Indians already pay about $80.00 a year for supplies, fuel and inspection of the school.

In May last when it was decided to place the school under the control of the Sisters after the holidays, Mr Agent Bastien was directed to inform Father Giroux that the Department was not to be put to any additional expense in the way of salary or equipment.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt on the 3rd instant of plans and specifications for the proposed repairs and alterations to the schoolhouse in the Baron village of Lorette, the cost of which you estimate will amount to $525.00.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th inst., sending me for my information plans and specifications for repairs to the schoolhouse at Lorette and informing me that the Department cannot grant the sum of $525.00 asked for by the Rev. Guil. Giroux for repairs to the schoolhouse, but that it is prepared to provide the sum of $200.00.

In reply I beg to say that I have just seen Rev. Mr. Giroux, whom I was not able to see sooner as he had been away from Lorette, and he requested me to write to you and ask whether the Department, which has agreed to grant $200.00 this year, would not be prepared to grant another sum of $200.00 next year in order to put the school into proper condition.

We believe, Mr. Giroux and I, that by leaving out the painting, which was included in the amount of $525.00, we should be able to put this building in a proper condition and to get a contractor for the carpentry work to wait for the remainder which would be granted next year. The reason why we make this request is that the upper part of the house is defective, is very low; it is hardly habitable, and it is really necessary that it be replaced by a French roof in order to afford proper lodging for the Sisters and to have two class-rooms sufficiently large and properly ventilated for the health of the school.
Will the Department therefore if possible accede to the present request by assuring us of the new grant of $200.00 next year. I await your reply on this point before sending you new specifications of the work to be undertaken.

I have, &c.,

Indian Agent.

Specification for repairs to the school at the Huron village of Jeune Lorette.

Three dormer windows to be put into the back of the building and two windows into the gable on the North-East side with double window for the class-room, and the floor of the class-room to be double of pine 1 and 1/2 inches thick.

The tie-beams to be raised to make a separation in the class-room of 24 feet which will come near the chimney to be made in upright joists and wainscoting on both sides.

All the inside of the class-room to be wainscoted in pine boards beaded 1 inch.

The plastering to be filled in with sawdust and the same to be placed over the ceiling. The stair to be made with a landing and balustrade above and two doors at the foot of the stair, one for the class-room below and the other for the upper class-room.

To fill up the door on the North-East side and to make closets with a door leading to them from each story, and to remove the old closets and the landing, and to make a new stair leading from the gallery on the chimney side.

To repair whatever is out of order in the gallery and to repair the roof of the building.

To reset the cross-beam below and to set up another on the first story with two pillars.

To repair the window-frames and glass, and to replaster them on the ground floor, and to divide the old class-room above into three apartments with two doors, and to do other little pieces of work of small importance that may be necessary, I bind myself to do this.

All the work shall be finished and handed
over by the beginning of September next.

I, the undersigned, bind myself to do all work enumerated above for the sum of $200.00.

Sir,

Referring to the alterations to be made in the Indian school at Lorette, I have the honour to reply to your letter of the 7th August last, and especially to the last paragraph of your letter of the 5th July, which reads as follows, "kindly advise the Department before proceeding with the repairs what work is proposed to be undertaken."

The Department decided not to expend more than the sum of $200.00 for necessary repairs to put the school in order for the Sisters who are going to teach there.

We could do the most necessary repairs for $200.00, and the specifications that I inclose is only for that amount. It was evident that that sum was not sufficient to meet the cost of doing the work completely, and the Department must have seen for itself on examination that that amount would not have been sufficient.

In the meantime, and almost immediately after the Department gave its consent to the expenditure of $200.00, The Honourable Solicitor General, Mr Fitzpatrick, on his way to Lorette, being conversant with the whole matter and devoted as always to the interests of his County and especially to the Huron tribe, wishing to give it a proof of his interest, generously personally subscribed the sum of $200.00 for the completion of the work so that on.
his special recommendation and after having come to an understanding with the Missionary the work was at once commenced for the sum of $400.00. This work was given to competent contractor, and will be completed shortly, the Department not having to expend more than $200.00 and getting first-class work.

I believe it was the actual desire of the Solicitor General that the work should begin at once, especially as the time was short and as the contractor was able at the time to put on a large number of workmen.

I should have liked to meet again The Honourable Solicitor General before giving this information to the Department, to which I hope everything will be agreeable.

I have, &c.,
Antoine O. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

Monsieur,

Un des membres de la tribu huronne, a construit l'an dernier, un aqueduc dans le village de Lorette, s'étant procuré l'eau à une bonne distance et à des frais assez considérables. Il distribue cette eau et en a déjà distribué à plusieurs familles sauvages de la Réserve à condition de $6.00 par année, et ces familles étant obligées de faire faire les travaux d'installation à leurs frais.

Je m'étais de me rencontrer avec M. le missionnaire, à l'école des sauvages, et les religieuses institutrices nous ont fait remarquer, et c'est un fait que j'avais déjà constaté, qu'elles sont obligées d'aller chercher l'eau à une bonne distance, ce qui leur est d'une très grande inconvénience, et leur cause beaucoup de misère pendant toute l'année, surtout pendant les mauvais temps d'hiver, ainsi qu'aux élèves qui sont chargés à tour de rôle, par les institutrices, de charroyer l'eau pour l'usage des deux classes.

J'ai vu l'ouvrier qui pose les appareils d'aqueduc ici, et après avoir mesuré les distances et minutieusement calculé, le coût d'installation de l'eau dans la maison d'école serait entre $15.00 à $20.00.

J'ai vu aussi le propriétaire de cet aqueduc, et comme faveur pour l'école, il consent à accepter la somme de $4.00 par année, au lieu de $6.00, [et ce n'est pas cher], qu'il charge à toutes les familles sauvages de la Réserve.
Au nom des religieuses, du missionnaire et en mon propre nom, je vous prie de vouloir bien autoriser de mettre l'eau dans l'école et de vouloir bien payer à l'avenir $4.00 par année pour cette eau.

Inutile de dire que l'installation de l'eau dans la maison d'école est une véritable nécessité, sans compter que ça ajoutera une valeur à la propriété plus grande que le coût de l'installation.

Comme la saison est beaucoup avancée, et que les gros froids vont bientôt nous arriver, le Département voudra bien en conséquence me donner, le plus tôt possible, l'autorisation requise, afin de faire faire les travaux avant que la terre ne soit trop gelée.

J'ai l'honneur d'être,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

[Signature]

Agent des sauvages.
Sir:

One of the members of the Huron Tribe constructed last year an aqueduct in the Lorette Village, thereby obtaining water from a great distance and at very considerable cost. He distributed this water and has since distributed it to several families of Indians of the Reserve on condition of paying $6.00 per year, and these families being obliged to have made the work of installation at their own cost.

I have just met the Missionary at the Indian School and the reverend sisters told us, and this is a fact which I had already been aware of, that they are obliged to bring water from a good distance, which puts them to great inconvenience and gives them much trouble during the whole year, but above all during the bad winter weather, also that their pupils are sent in their turn according to the role by the teachers to bring the water for the use of the two classes.

I have seen the workman who prepared this aqueduct and after having measured the distances and calculated minutely, the cost of installation of the water in the school-house will be between $15.00 and $20.00.

I have also seen the owner of this aqueduct, and, as a favour to the school, he consented to accept the sum of $4.00 per annum, instead of $6.00 (and this is not dear), which he charges all the families of Indians of the Reserve.

In the name of the sisters, of the Missionary and of myself, I beg you to be good enough to authorize the putting of the water in the school and to be good enough to pay in future $4.00 per year for this water.

It is needless to say that the installation of the water in the school-house is a real necessity, not counting that this
this adds a greater value to the property than the cost of the installation.

As the season is well advanced and the severe weather will soon be upon us, the Department will be kind enough, therefore, to give me as soon as possible, the required authority so that I may have the work done before the ground becomes too much frozen.

I have, &c.,

Antoine O. Bastien,
Indian Agent.

J'ai l'honneur de vous transmettre le compte de Mr. Maurice Bastien, pour avoir fourni l'eau de la Réserve des Sauvages de Lorette, du 1er Décembre 1902 au 1er Décembre 1903. Le Département voudra bien voir à payer ce compte.

Dear Mr. Hector:

You will find herewith a copy of the petition which we address at the same time to Mr. Pedley, Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

I have had the honour of receiving at my boarding-house at Ludger Bastien's the Hon. Fitzpatrick accompanied by Mr. Pedley, who showed themselves well disposed towards obtaining for us the amount necessary to build a school in the Village, inasmuch as the present school is held in what was the former residence of the missionaries, restored and converted into a monastery and into classes for the Huron children.

As I am the resident missionary, I reclaim my residence, so that the Government will be obliged to grant us a new school, which, I hope, will be more comfortable and better situated than the present school.

The Minister suggested to me to inform you of and to send you a copy of the request in order that you will know its tenor and that you will look after and press its execution.

I would like to believe that you will recall to Mr. Pedley his promise to send us a favourable reply within a few weeks so that we may commence the undertaking at once.

Counting on your kindness, I hope that you will aid me in this request and that you will bring to the Deputy Superintendent's attention that this $2,000 should be taken from the subsidies voted each year for poor Indians and not from the funds of the Band as was intended by the Hon. OTTAWA, 19th October, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the petition hereunder from the Missionary and Chiefs of the Huron Tribe of Lorette for a grant of not less than $2,000.00 for the construction of a schoolhouse on the reserve, I beg to say that the evidence on file in this Department does not go to show that the present school building was intended for the presbytery or residence of the former missionaries. I find that in March 1879 Rev. Father Boucher, then missionary at Lorette, forwarded an estimate of the cost of the new schoolhouse which was valued at $1148.65 and required a further expenditure of some $250.00 to complete it. There was nothing said as to its being built for the missionary's residence.

When the muns were given charge of this school in July 1900, it was understood that the Department was not to be put to any additional expense in any way, other than making certain needed repairs and it expended $250.00 for this purpose, which was supplemented by a gift of $200.00 from Hon. Mr Fitzpatrick.

I do not see that the Department is under any obligation to relinquish this school building or erect a new one. It appears to me that the missionary is trying to get possession of the building for a presbytery, knowing that if successful, the Department will
will have to put up a new schoolhouse.

The building apparently belongs to the Band but as they have no funds to build a new schoolhouse and there are none available, I do not think they should be allowed to turn it over to the missionary for a residence. They have had a missionary on the reserve from time immemorial and it is rather late in the day to be looking for a residence for them.

Martin Thomson

Memorandum: Mr. Pedley.

The school at Lorette was erected by the Roman Catholic Church in 1879, in which year a grant of $100 was made by the Department towards its maintenance. Previous to that time the school had been in receipt of a sum of $120 per annum, first from the Old Province of Canada, and afterwards from the Province of Quebec, but was discontinued in that year. In 1880 the amount given by the Department was increased to $200 per annum to pay the salary of the teacher. This amount was recently increased to $300 a year. In 1900 the Department allowed $200 towards repairs to the building.

The Department considers it one of its duties to see that schools are provided on all Indian Reserves. When the funds of the band admit of it the necessary amount is taken therefrom; but when they have not sufficient funds the money is provided by vote of Parliament.

Asst. Secretary.
