To Mr. Kelley,
Deputy Minister,
Dept. of I.T., Ottawa.

Sir,

You are aware that since the month of October last we the Huron chiefs and I have written more than once in regard to a grant of a certain sum of money to build a new school-house in the village. The following were the reasons:

1. That school is held in the house and on the land belonging to the church of the band and formerly the residence of the missionaries.

2. That I am at present the resident missionary, and have no house.

3. That the chiefs and A
claim this land and house for a presbyterian.

4. That therefore the Dept. ought to authorize the building of a new school-house in order to give up the church property; and to obtain a vote of the money necessary for this purpose as soon as possible in order that school may open in the month of September.

5. That we have the promise of the Minister of Justice, our Member, and of yourself, Rev. Padley, who accompanied the minister to the place a few weeks before the election last autumn, that the Govt. would vote us this money during the present session, as this work is urgent.

In a petition from the undersigned to the Dept. in October last, and advised by yourself and the Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick, the petitioners asked for the sum
of $2500; and the Minister informed us some days before the election that the Govt. would vote us $1500. Besides he declared to me in two personal letters that that was understood between himself and the Govt.

Now it is already late, there remain only two months for us to conclude school-house, the session is drawing to a close, and both the Minister and the Dept. keep silent about all our claims.

However I beg to inform the Dept. that the present school no longer conforms to the requirements of health (1) because the height of the ceiling is only 8 feet; while the law requires 10 feet at least; (2) because the cabinets & closets, opening into the class-rooms, are a source of pestilence to the children and to the teachers and are a veritable danger to their health.
On account of all these reasons and others, we beg the Dept. to be diligent in rendering us justice, and to send an inspector, if it thinks necessary, to be convinced of these facts; otherwise at the risk of seeing this school closed by the Board of Health and the Indian children deprived of their school this fall.

As you see, sir, this is not altogether a favour that we ask as an act of justice on the part of the Govt.

Yours truly,

P. R. Godbout, priest,
missionary

Monsieur le ministre,

Bien que je n'aie pas l'honneur de vous connaître personnellement et qu'il n'y ait pas longtemps encore que vous occupez le poste honorable de ministre, cependant la renommée vous a fait connaître et la nouvelle de votre élection a été applaudie aussi bien par les Canadiens-français et Catholiques de Québec, que par vos compatriotes et corégionnaires de votre Province. Permettez à un humble et pauvre prêtre de vous présenter ses plus sincères félicitations et de vous offrir ses hommages les plus respectueux.

Il s'agit maintenant d'apporter à votre connaissance ce qui dont il est question dans cette lettre.

J'ai été appelé par mon supérieur ecclésiastique à être le missionnaire résidant des Hurons de Lorette depuis le mois d'octobre dernier. Jusqu'à cette date l'église des Hurons était desservie par le curé de la paroisse voisine; mais cette desserte ne pouvait plus se faire, et étant de plus déclarée imparfaite et insuffisante par qui de droit, le conseil de la tribu demanda et obtint un prêtre résidant non-seulement pour la desservir au spirituel mais encore pour veiller au bon ordre et à la morale publique, mais c'est tait aux deux conditions suivantes:

1. Qu'il serait donné à ce missionnaire un salaire d'au moins cinq à six cents piastres par année;
2. Qu'il serait logé convenablement.

Huron Village of Lorette, August 4, 1905.

The Hon. Mr. Oliver,
Minister of the Interior,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Although I have not the honour of knowing you personally and although you have not long occupied the honourable position of Minister, nevertheless, your nomination has made you known and the news of your election has been well received, not only by the French Canadians and Roman Catholics of Quebec but by your compatriots and co-religionists of your own province. Permit a humble and poor priest to present you his most sincere congratulations and to offer his respects.

I may now bring to your attention the subject of this letter.

I was appointed by the church authorities as resident missionary to the Hurons of Lorette and have occupied this position since the month of October, last. Up to that time the services in the Huron church were conducted by the curé of the neighbouring parish, but as this service could no longer be continued, and it having, moreover, been declared imperfect and insufficient by those who had a right to say, the council of the tribe asked for and obtained a resident priest, not only to administer to their spiritual wants but also to preserve good order and public morality, but this was done on the two following conditions:

1. That there would be given to this missionary a salary of not less than $500 or $600 per year.
2. That he would be suitably lodged.
Since that time a petition was sent to the Dept. asking for this salary; and it was only after several months that the amount of $200 was granted, to be added to the 50 pounds sterling which was formerly paid to the former non-resident missionary.

You will admit, Sir, that a salary of $425 is quite insufficient to keep a house, furnish it and maintain it. However, your predecessor, the Hon. Mr. Sifton claimed that it was sufficient and fixed this sum, notwithstanding the Honourable, the Minister of Justice, our member, and the Huron Chiefs, who wished to grant more.

2. When the matter of lodging came up, our member, the Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick, and Mr. Pedley, the Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs, went to the place before the elections in the month of Nov., last. They declared that the government could furnish nothing for churches or presbyteries, but that it could and ought to for the schools. Now, the present school is nothing but the residence of the former missionaries; as it was not used they fixed it up and turned it into a school-house; it is joined to the church, placed on the land of the church and, consequently, the property of the church. And now I, an resident missionary, claim this house to make of it a residence, as I have no residence and cannot get any other.

A petition was addressed to the Dept. in the month of October, last, asking for $2,000 to construct a school intended for the teaching of the Huron children; the reply was given that the matter would be considered. the Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick promised us that there would be voted for us out of the funds of the government not less
than $1500 during the last session; and now Mr. Pedley tells us that nothing was done.

The Dept. has, therefore, acted unjustly towards us, and I am confident, Sir, that you will render justice to us now,

To assure yourself of the justice of my request and of the truth of what I have said, I refer you to the Hon. Charles Fitzpatrick, our member, and to the department, where you will find documents in support thereof.

Besides, the house where the classes are held does not comply with the hygienic conditions required by the government and the board of health; because in place of 10 feet between the floors there is only 8 and because the water-closets open into the class-rooms are a source of pestilence. The Dept. has already been notified of this but has not replied.

Finally, the work of repairs that are necessary and the remuneration that the Church will require to allow the classes to be held there in the future, since it needs the building as a lodging for its missionary, will amount to more than the sum asked for to construct a new building.

Yours faithfully,
P.A. Godbout, Priest.
Missionary.

The Superintendent,

Sir,

I have already complained of the deplorable state, with reference to hygiene, of the school-rooms of the Huron children of Lorette. No one has condescended to reply. I conclude from this that there is more than negligence; there is also unwillingness. I repeat it, that the state of affairs is intolerable. The privies, which are far from being water-closets, have been full for some years; opening into the class-rooms, they are a continual pest; at certain times it becomes necessary to stop the classes and send the children out in order that they will not be asphyxiated. There is no ventilator other than the windows, which cannot always be left open.

Moreover, instead of being 10 ft. from floor to ceiling it is only 8½ ft.

But, if this were a Protestant school, this condition of affairs would not be tolerated for a week, and here it has gone on for some years.

I am obliged to purchase lime to disinfect a little, and I suppose that when it is asked to pay for this expenditure the government will object. If the Dept. wished to be just to me it would vote me a reasonable salary and permit me to take the present school for a presbytery, since it is the former residence of the missionaries.
If it is decided finally to vote the $2000, or at least $1500, to build a suitable school-house, I shall be able to meet these expenses and still others for the welfare of these poor children. But when one has the ridiculous salary of $425 and when one is obliged to look for his board or lodgings where it cannot always be found, it is difficult to be very liberal.

That is the position in which I am put by the government, which has some millions coming from Indian reserves, and of which it ought to employ at least a little for the benefit of the Indians.

I ask the Dept. to see that this question of our school is settled, otherwise I shall be obliged to have the officers of the board of health intervene.

A reply is urgent.

Your humble servant,
P. A. Jodbout, priest,
Missionary.

Ottawa, 5th Oct., 1905.

Memorandum:

Lorette Church Property,

The Roman Catholic Church had missionaries settled on the Lorette Reserve by the authority of the French Government long before the Province came into the possession of Great Britain.

The Indians had been under the especial care and direction of the missionaries who had obtained grants of land for them from the French Crown to be applied to their education and civilization, the missionaries themselves being their instructors.

The Treaty of Paris provided that the Indians should have liberty of religion and should be allowed to keep their missionaries. The Church properties held by the R.C. missionaries on the reserves in Lower Canada previous to the conquest were retained by them without their right to the same being questioned.

Grants were made both by the Indian Department and the Provincial Government towards the erection
erection of church and school buildings; but these grants were not held to constitute a claim to ownership of the buildings, although it would, it is thought, lay the Church authorities under the obligation to use them for the purpose for which they were stated to be intended when the grants were asked for and made.

There is no doubt but that the building erected in 1869 was built to be used for a school, and the grants made to it were on that understanding. In the correspondence regarding it the missionary always referred to it as a school house. In a letter of the 23rd March, 1876, the Rev. Mr. Boucher said, - "I have insured the school house for $800 with the Farmers Insurance Co. I paid $15.00 premium for three years for the policy. The house is built on the village land and belongs to the village.

"Will the Department be good enough to pay for the insurance, the village being extremely poor. They cannot contribute anything to the support of the school."

In reply Mr. Boucher was informed that the Department could not pay more than $100 per annum towards the school building in question.

Asst. Secretary.

Memorandum:

Deputy Superintendent General,

I have been considering the best means of financing the project of a new school house on Lorette Reserve. This Band has now about $8,600.00 at credit or capital account which bears interest at three per cent. When full payments for the Roomont Reserve shall have been made, the full amount of capital will be about $17,000.00. At three per cent., this will give them an annual revenue of $510.00. Against this revenue they have pledged an annual payment of $200.00 to their Priest, and the balance which remains is fully needed to provide for the maintenance of insane members of the Band and casual relief charges. If we take from the capital any considerable amount, it will of course weaken the interest. I think, however, that the Band could afford to assist in meeting the expense of building the school house to the extent of half the cost. I think that $1,500.00 or at the most $2,000.00 should provide a building well adapted for the purpose and with proper modern conveniences. If the Band consents to pay half the expense, we can provide the balance from current appropriations without asking the House for a special vote. The building will not be finished before the 30th of June next so that I will be able to divide our share of the expenditure between two fiscal years. I do not think we could afford to pay the whole cost of the school house without a special appropriation; and, having due consideration for the circumstances of these Indians, I do not think the Government ought to be asked to meet the whole cost. Although it is our policy to build school houses where they are required and to keep them in good repair, we always expect the
the Indian funds to bear the cost if they can do so without impoverishing the funds; and throughout the Provinces of Ontario and Quebec a large majority of the school buildings are the property of the Indians having been erected from their own capital.

Ottawa, 1st December, 1924

Ottawa, 16th March, 1906.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

The condition of the closets at the Indian school at Jeune Lorette, north of the city of Quebec, was brought to the attention of the Department on the 18th October last. On the 28th a plan was sent for the construction of two new buildings. Before this arrived "the Missionary" had decided to have a closet with water attachment constructed inside of the school, and the works were commenced before the Agent received our instructions. At that date, the 21st, he stated the accounts would be sent here for payment.

We have now received the accounts amounting to $150.63, or over twice the cost of the buildings authorized by the Department.

There is no doubt apparently that the closet now built is a much better arrangement than the one authorized by the Department. It, however, is rather a bad precedent for anyone to take upon himself the responsibility of having any work done of this nature without the authority of the Department. I beg to submit the matter for your consideration. I think also the Agent is to blame in not having stopped, or at least protested against such work being undertaken without the authority of the Department.

Chief Surveyor.

Sir,

The balance available from this interest account, after paying the usual drafts on it, will not admit for a long time the payment of the above mentioned sum of $130.63. I have to ask you to inform me how it is proposed that this money shall be paid.

If the Deptt. will refer to correspondence under the above number, it will see that reiterated requests have been made by the Council and the members of the Huron Band of Prette for the erection of a school-house in the village.

The Deputy Deptt. General, Mr. Frank Bailey, without making formal promises, by his letter of July 29, 1905, to the Rev. Mr. Godbout, missionary, seemed favourable to the project, but said that at the time there were no funds available.

The Chiefs asked me to call the attention of the Deptt. to the subject, and as Parliament is in session, it would be an easy matter to place in the estimates about £1,500.00 for

Ottawa, Dec. 7, 1908.

Memorandum for

Deputy Minister,

In reply to your verbal enquiries, I beg to state that there appears to be no correspondence showing that either the Indians or Lorette or the ecclesiastical authorities have made a promise to defray any portion of the cost of the construction of the proposed new School house on the reserve.

The amount voted for the purpose is $1500. The plans it appears are suitable, and should if possible be adopted. The tenders received were two one for $1800 and the other for $2700.

Mr. Ogilvie, in his memorandum hereunder states that the tender for $1800 is a particularly low one, unless he has special facilities. Mr. Ogilvie's estimate is shown to be $2346.16 for this work, and in addition there still remains to be provided for the construction of a drain and cement floors and a furnace at an estimated cost $406.00. The total estimated cost for the complete work is $2652.16, and as stated above there is only $1500 available to meet this expenditure. If however, the contract is awarded for $1800, we have then a deficit of $706.00 to provide.

I beg to draw your attention to the memorandum from the Accountant of the 1st Dec., 1908 in which he recommends that the Hurons of Lorette should contribute towards the construction of the proposed School house. I beg to recommend that the Agent be instructed to inform the band that the Department has at its disposal the sum of $1500.00 for the erection of the building and they should pass a resolution recommending that the balance required namely, $1152.00 (according to Mr. Ogilvie's estimate) be taken from their capital funds.
If it should appear that the person tendering to construct the building for $1800 has special facilities, the Department would be justified in letting the work to him, the balance required would be only as stated above $706.00. I think it would be better for the Indians to ask the authority for the larger sum, namely $1152.

Please also see the memorandum from Mr. Stewart, dated 26 Oct., in which he states "The Department considers it one of its duties to see that schools are provided to all Indian reserves. When the funds of the band admit of it the necessary amount is taken therefrom; but when they have not sufficient funds the money is provided by vote of parliament."
Ottawa, Dec. 10, 1906.

Referring to your letter of the 8th ult., I have the request you to inform the Indian Council that the cost of the proposed new school house is estimated by the Architect of the Department at $2552.00. This includes the drain, furnace, and cement floors which are not provided for in the specifications on which you called for tenders.

The Department has the sum of $1500 available for the construction of the school. There is, therefore, a balance of $1052 to be provided to make up the sum according to the estimate above mentioned.

You will please inform the Indians that they should pass a resolution requesting that the said sum of $1052.00 be taken from their capital funds for the purposes required.

The tender received for $1000 is considered to be a particularly low one unless the contractor has some special facilities for procuring his labour and materials. In the event of the department accepting this tender, the total extra sum required will be $706.00. It is considered advisable that the Indians should pass a resolution for the greater sum ($1152) of course only such portion of this sum will be spent as may be required.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of I.A., Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to reply to your letter of December 10, in which you submitted the Department's letter to the Indian Council, and this is what was decided.

Firstly, the tender of Mr Verret, amounting to $1,800.00, did not appear to them to be too low. You say in your letter that the contractor could not build at that price what is contained in the special conditions and obtain the labour and material cheaply. Mr Verret is in this position. He can obtain the lumber in the parish of St. Ambroise; he has a saw-mill where he can make all the lumber and sashes and frames (doors); besides if the contract is given him as soon as possible, he will have two or three months until the snow melts to attend to the mat-

The chiefs have examined the plans and they are satisfied with them. At their meeting they decided to grant only $500.00 of their funds, which with the $1,500.00 voted by Parliament, will make $2,000.00. Out of the $500.00 that they are giving, $300.00 will serve to make up the difference between the sum tendered by Parliament and the $1,800.00 asked for by Mr Verret and the other $200.00 will be used to bring the water to the school, to put in the water-closets and to make a drain.

With reference to the furnaces, they prefer for the present to keep the stoves that they have in the old school. Later on, when they have more money, they will be able to change the system of heating. Besides, all the schools of the French-Canadians in the parishes are heated with wood and by stoves. We shall thus have a good school completely finished, provided with water, water-closets and a drain. All agree in saying that Mr Verret's tender, amounting to $1,800.00, is the most advantageous that we can have and that, owing to the position of the tenderer, he can carry out his contract perfectly and make a reasonable
profit. Besides, we can exact a guarantee from him, bonds.

The Indians hope that the question will be settled in this manner and that Verret's tender will be accepted as soon as possible by the Department. In that case will the Department kindly acquaint me with its views as soon as possible in order that I may get the Indian Council to pass a regular resolution for $500.00 to be taken out of their funds.

I have, etc.,

A. O. Bastien,

The undersigned begs to report that, in order to construct a new school house, at a cost of $1800.00, on the reserve of the Hurons of Lorette, in the County and Province of Quebec, the sum of $1500 was voted by Parliament last Session and the Indians have passed a resolution to provide the balance of $300 from their capital and an additional $300 from the same source to provide means of bringing water to the school, to install closets and to make a drain in connection therewith.

As this work when completed would be in the nature of a permanent improvement and properly represent capital, the undersigned begs to recommend that, under the provisions of Sec. 90 of the Indian Act (Chap. 61 R. S. C.), authority be given for the expenditure thereon of the $500 above mentioned from the capital at the credit of the Huron Indians of Lorette, which amounts to $11,654.84.

The building hitherto used as a school is now to be used as a residence for the Rev. Father Godbout, who was recently located on the reserve as resident missionery. The mission will remember that the Hon. Mr. Fitzpatrick and Mr. Bailey visited the reserve in connection with this matter.

$1800, the amount of the present tender—which was accepted—is very low. The running expenses of the band, however, are too heavy to permit of any considerable sum being taken from band funds, and the Public Works Appropriation of $1500 was obtained last Session. The band has contributed $300 to make up the balance of the tender, and a further $200 to bring water to the school, install water closets therein and make a drain.

With reference to the erection of the school-house in the Sunan village, I should like to ask the attention of the Department to a proposed change. According to the specifications, the contractor is to lay the walls, the partitions, and the ceiling of the storey where the teachers (nuns) will reside; and the said contractor is ready to follow the specifications to the letter. The missionary, the Rev. Mr. Giroux, and I, after a most minute examination of the specifications, believe that certain changes ought to be made.

First, for the ceiling of the teachers' storey it is desired that this should be of wood, because it would be much warmer, more solid, and consequently more durable. Monsieur,

J'ai l'honneur d'informer le Département que les travaux de la maison d'école du village sont terminés et complétés à la satisfaction du missionnaire et de moi-même.

L'entrepreneur Mr. Gaudias Verret, m'a demandé de vouloir bien informer le Département qu'il désirerait être payé de la balance de son entreprise, soit, de la somme de $800.00.

Je ne vois aucun inconvénient à ce que le Département paie cette balance de $800.00, attendu que l'entrepreneur n'a pas fait fortune avec cette entreprise.

Maintenant, il va falloir 20 châssis doubles pour la bâtisse, ce qui n'était pas prévu par les spécifications. En référant aux spécifications que m'a fournies le Département, je ne vois pas que cet item ait été prévu, et l'entrepreneur prétend qu'il n'est pas obligé de faire des doubles châssis pour l'hiver. Ces doubles châssis coûteraient dans les environs de $50.00. Je laisse au Département le soin de décider la chose et de m'écrire le plus tôt possible, sur ce point.

Je crois avec le missionnaire et les chefs, que le Département autorisera la confection de ces châssis doubles, qui sont absolument nécessaire, à être payés à même les fonds votés pour les écoles des sauvages de la Province de Québec.

La bâtisse de l'école étant terminée, il faudrait y conduire
le drainage ainsi que l'eau, et y installer les water-closets.

Par Résolution de la Bande en date du 26 janvier 1907, transmise au Département par ma lettre du 28 janvier 1907, ce dernier devait, sur les $800.00 souscrites par la bande, payer la somme de $300.00 à l'entrepreneur Verret pour combler la différence entre la somme de $1500.00 votée par le Parlement, et celle de $1800.00 prix de l'entreprise, et les autres $200.00 devant servir pour conduire l'eau à l'école, installer des water-closets et faire un drain. Or, vu que ces travaux doivent être faits par des journaliers et des ouvriers qui ont besoin de leur argent au fur et à mesure que se font les travaux, je demanderais au Département de m'adresser cette somme de deux cents dollars, afin de défrayer le coût de ces travaux.

I have the honour to inform the Dept. that the work on the village school-house is finished to the thorough satisfaction of the missionary and myself. The contractor, Mr. Gaudias Verret, has asked me to inform the Dept. that he would like to be paid the balance of his contract, namely, $800. I do not see any reason why the Dept. should not pay this balance, inasmuch as the contractor has not made much out of this contract.

Now there are still wanting 20 double windows for the building, which were not provided for in the specifications.

On referring to the specifications that the Dept. furnished me, I do not see that this item was provided for, and the contractor contends that he is not obliged to make double windows for winter. These windows would cost about $50. I leave it to the Dept. to decide the matter and to write me as soon as possible as to this point. I believe with the missionary and the chiefs that the Dept. will authorize the making of these double windows, which are absolutely necessary, to be paid out of the funds voted for Indian schools in the province of Quebec.

The school building being finished, it is necessary to connect the drainage with it and also water, and to provide water-closets.
By resolution of Jan. 26, 1907, transmitted to the Dept. in my letter of Jan. 28, 1907, the Dept. was out of the $500 subscribed by the band to pay the $300 to Contractor Verret to make up the difference between the $1500 voted by Parliament and $1800, the amount of the contract, and the other $200 was to be spent in bringing water to the school, putting in water-closets and making a drain. Now, as this work has to be done by workmen who need their money in proportion as the work progresses, I would ask the Dept. to send me this sum of $200 in order to pay the expense of the work.

There is no time to lose, as the winter is coming on.

Memo.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I beg to inform you that on Thursday December 19, I made an inspection of the new school building at Jeune Lorette.

The building is erected in accordance with the plans and specifications excepting that two interior stone walls in basement have not been put in. The position of basement stairway changed and a trap door put in instead of going down under main stairs.

The woodwork and joining generally appears to be strongly put together. It is, however, very rough and no portions have been hand smoothed.

There is a good system of plumbing established and the water supply brought into the building.

The contractor for the building is ill and I was therefore unable to interview him. I have been credibly informed, however, that he has sustained a loss of about $250. on the contract and the stonework will cost to complete about $40. to $45.

The Chief of the Band and Sisters in charge of the school express themselves as being very well satisfied with the building and the accommodations provided. The Sisters ask for a partition across hall at head of stairs to prevent cold draughts ascending to upper portions of house at a cost of $25. and I would recommend that this be done.

Architect.

Sir,
